div1.p: THE ROMAN REVENGE. A TRAGEDY. By AARON HILL, Esq
Sold by M. Mechell, at the King's arms in Fleet-street; and likewise to be had at the Booksellers of London and Westminster. M,DCC,LIII. Price one Shilling and Six-pence.]

lg.l: TELL me, ye matchless Fair! Ye fearless Brave!
Is there one Briton— born to be a Slave?
No.—While your Prince half Europe's Rights maintains,
Nor Souls, nor Bodies, here, can stoop to Chains.
Angels, and Englishmen, like Homage, pay:
Bow, but, from Love,—and, but by Choice obey:
I oyal, to keason's Rights, not Slavery's Awe,
The Sons of Freedom serve the Kings, of Law.
Act, with no Clogs on Sense, no Clouds on Art,
But let in Truth's whole Light, to hear the Heart.
Such, once, was Rome-to Strength, not Luxury, train'd:
Then Liberty was Hers, and Virtue reign'd:
Safe, in her own felt Power, and bluntly brave,
She scorn'd alike to be— or make— a Slave.
No puny Popeling, yet, Man's Birth-right Stole:
Foe, to th' invaded Empire—of the SOUL!
Plain, prideless Rule bound short Ambition's Plea:
But left Thought, Art, Faith, Hope, and Conscience free.
Far other Fame was hers, when Church-craft reign'd,
Then, every Cherub's Face, with Gall, was stain'd:
Sweet-ey'd Religion, sow'rd, by priestly Leaven,
Frown'd on pale Peace—and shook her Keys at Heaven.
More than her Maker's Rights, She found too small,
And murmur'd, that his Grants cou'd give —but ALL.
Wil'd, Inconsistent, Blasphemous, and Vain,
Revers'd God's Laws—to propogate his Reign!
Her Creeds taught Curses.—Her proud Schools Debate
Nothing, but Fool, a Flattery, 'scap'd her Hate.
She lov'd Obedience,—but she lov'd it, blind:
And, safelier to subdue, debas'd Mankind.
No Pardon, there, let Britain's Sins presume;
Freedom, and Truth, are HERETICS—at Rome.
Religion's Dark'ners will no Reverence feel
For Faith, that bears no Craft, and blinds no Zeal:
Learning, uncurb'd by Cant; Truth, wash'd from Wiles,
An Earth, that Reasons—and a Heaven that smiles:
Homage, that no Sedition can betray,
Yet Liberty, that laughs at lawless Sway.
Such had the World's vain Mistress, then, been fram'd,
When this Night's Story Rome's Attention claim'd;
Freedom had nurs'd no Son, to blast her Reign,
And Caesar had a Soul, without one Stain.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: Marcus Brutus, his Son by Servilia, but not knowing himself to be so.
Torbilius; A Roman Poet, favour'd by Brutus.
Trinovantius, A British Tribune, faithful to Caesar.
Curio A Roman Tribune, in his Confidence.
An Augur: Officers, Lictors, and Plebeians.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: Flavia, A Lady, Attendant on Calphurnia.

set.p: SCENE. The Capital, and Places adjoing.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: STAY! turn!—The imperfect Dawn deceives my Sight,
Or, 'tis Torbilius.

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Cassius:

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: He!—How comes it,
I meet thee, in the House of hated Caesar!

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Portia, to-night, was frighted, in a Dream;
And, hast'ning hither, to alarm Calphurmia,
Call'd for my Hand, to guide her.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: In the Forum.
Expect strong Clash, this Morning.

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Will Caesar, then,
Be King.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: He will—yet, Dreams of a to-morrow.

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: So dies, our Plot abortive.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Rather, die Caesar!
Fix Brutus ours—and yon pale—rising Sun
Shall drink the Tyrant's Blood, before its setting.

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Speak softly.—'Tis an unsafe Scene, for Treason.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Not now.—The House is Desart.—Every Eye,
Busied remote, strays upward, from the Grove;
Hard, thro' dim Dawn, the Patient Augurs pore,
Watchful to teach mysterious Birds, to lie,
And mock insulted Heaven, to flatter Caesar.

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Wait you the Auguries?

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Away—light Questioner!
Brutus, and I, with more tame Slaves, call'd Senators,
Last Night, beseeching Audience, kingly Caesar
Told us, fair Meanings shun'd the Shade of Night,
And bad us, when Day rose, attend his Pleasure:
I came a willing Hour too soon—for, oh!
Such a Discovery!—Such Intelligence!

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Whence flows it?

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Whence do all Court Secrets flow?
Kings trust their Minions—and King-Blasters bribe 'em:
Caesar, to-night, sat writing, till alarmed,
He heard Calphurnia shriek, and rose to aid her.
Left, in his Closet, lay a half transcrib'd,
And strangely—purpos'd WILL:—wherein who (think'st thou)
But Brutus!—Our last Hope—Rome's freeborn Brutus!
Is nam'd the Tyrant's SON! and Heir of Empire!

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: In Form of Will adopted?

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Direly; adopted!
Own'd his true natural-born decendant Son,
By Cato's solemn Sister!—Curse her Hypocrisy!
'Twas Ruin—to the Hopes of Rome, and Liberty.

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: What Bribe had Power, to force a Friend from Caesar.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Thy Friend, and mine—imperial Gold!—more Eloquent,
Than ten smooth Caesars! bought a true King-Server
From his Lord's Bosom,—Opportunely near,
He caught the inviting Moment:—left his Covert,—
Read—started—sent to press my early coming,
And, private here, in the still dusk, discolosed it.

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Gods! What persidious Friendships cheat Mankind!

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Laugh, and be wise.—So, to betray, gives Greatness.
—Forget not thou, mean-while, to speed thy Charge:
Prepare cold Brutus for the Day's Impression:
Swell him, with all his prais'd Forefather's Pride;
Fume his enhaling Soul with Flatte'ry's Incence,
And share divided Rome's best Hopes, with Cassius

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Why must Rome's Hopes depend on One Man's Aid?

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: All Men are Ours in Brutus.—Thou, and I,
And every Roman, leagu'd, to cut off Caesar,
Hate Caesar.—Every burning Breast, but His,
Has sep'arate, inselt, private Cause, for Malice:
Who will believe, we strike for Rome.—So known,
So mark'd, malignant to the Name of Caesar?
Brutus is Caesar's Idol!—and loves Caesar!
His Aid will consecrate Revenge to Virtue.
He can, when Caesar bleeds, turn Tears to Triumph,
And blot the whitest Star, that lights his Character.

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: But this is Baseness, Cassius!—grant it needful,
The Man shou'd die—why must we kill his Virtues?
Why, to oppose his reigning, must we rob
His natural Rights?—why shade the Soul, he shines by?
No—let us own the Beauties of his Heart:
Weeping, confess his Brave'ry, Tempe'rence, Pity,
Long patient Courtings of rejected Peace—
Yet—dreadful Darings, in Contempt of Danger?
Else, we shall spot Laws Face, with Marks of Envy,
Treating this vastness of a Mind, like Heaven's,
As if keen-ey'd for Guilt, but blind to Goodness.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Perish his Goodness!—grind my Ear no more
With his curst Qualities:—I hate his Power:
I hate myself—hate Rome—hate Life, Joy, Victory,
Hate every Hope, but one.—to make Him feel,
That slighted Cassius drew down Fate on Caesar.
This let me live to teach him—Then,—tho' Rome,
Sunk, round me, till her tumbling Capital
Smoak'd, for my funeral Pile.—'Twere Death, with Glory.

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Cassius! my Soul, less fiery, cannot strain
Resentment into Frenzy:—In my Sense,
Reason, not Rage, shou'd measure Plotter's Passions.
Be temperate, or

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: By Heaven! he comes! you Gallery
Sounds, with his Step.—The holy Farce is ended:
Poet,—farewell.—

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Farewell, detested Envy!
Motives like thine, turn Justice into Murder.
Something shall, strait, be done.—Caesar! be safe:
He, who forgave my Guilt, demands my Virtue.

div2.head: SCENE II.
div2.stage: CAESAR, Preceded by Lictors, and Officers, and follow'd at some Distance, by an Augur.

sp.speaker: AUGUR.
sp.l: Caesar! imperial Caesar! hear the Gods.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Go:—Thou art known.—The Gods, thou serv'st, are Senators:
Cassrus, thy Phaebus—and his Gold, thy Jove.

sp.speaker: AUGUR.
sp.l: Rest, from this fatal March, restrain'd by Heaven,
And, by such unpropitious Auguries, warn'd.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Shame on your pious Frauds! they tire Indulgence.

sp.speaker: AUGUR.
sp.l: Check not the Voice of Truth: 'twas form'd, for Plainness.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Own it with conscious Shame.—If Truth loves Plainness.
Why are the God's clear Wills perplex'd, by Art?

sp.speaker: AUGUR.
sp.l: Speaks Rome's high Pontiff This?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: He does, bold Augur!
'To rescue Zeal, from Pride's unhallow'd Claim;
That robs, to reve'rence Heaven.

sp.speaker: AUGUR.
sp.l: Heaven calls for Faith.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: How dare you, then, make Infidels, by Falsehood?
Wou'd you, o're Reason, stretch the Chain of Faith,
Gild it, with Heaven's broad Light: Touch the taught Heart.
Nobly, speak out:—and tell th' attracted World,
Nothing is from the Gods, that shakes Man's Honesty.

sp.speaker: AUGUR.
sp.l: Oh! stay thy fatal March—change thy rash Views;
Bid thy rais'd Eagles fall the expanded Wing:
Air's plumy People, screaming from the Left,
Stoop in their Flight, to warn Thee:—Omens on Omens,
Bode unauspecious Doom—and teem, with Death.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Augur
sp.l: the Gods

sp.speaker: Caesar
sp.l: away—I know 'em, best,
Who know 'em Friends to Virtue.—

sp.speaker: AUGUR.
sp.l: Virtue is Liberty.
The Foes of Freedom can attract no Gods,
To prop their falling Standards;—Heaven beglooms
Thy Star, with some dire Fate:—but what, is Darkness.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Go: search it, in the Air,—and, if thou find'st it,
Arm'd, in its ugliest Menace, bring it hither.—
When Screams of Birds can shake a Soldier's Heart,
Thou shalt lead Priests to fight, for feeble Rome,
And lend their Arts, to Caesar.

sp.speaker: AUGUR.
sp.l: Tremble.—

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: I wou'd, be happy.—Why, then, am I Great?
Men, who desert their Peace, to serve their Glory,
Toil, for the Malice of oblig'd Mankind:
Yet—weigh, warm Heart, impartially sincere,
Whence Opposition Springs—and Love its Boldness.
Why claim I Power Supreme?—was Empire—mine?
Freedom is every Roman's native Right;
And every Roman Voice demands it back,
Where Power's, unjustly, held—the Opposer's just:
But,—where even Freedom is, by Choice, corrupt,
How fruitless—to redeem the willing Slave.
Can I recall the Dead?—Rome gives up Rome;
The cheapen'd Varlets rate their venal Votes,
And sell their Soul's Redeemer.—Sleep, Ambition?
How easier 'tis to save, than mend, a People!
Fall, servile Rome!—No.—Rome is Caesar's Country.
And, who dares injure, where he's born—to save?
Foes! wrong me on—till pardon'd into Friends:
Busy, for Greatness, I'll neglect Revenge;
Take Envy in Reward, and make it Fame.
What new, kind Fear, alarms thy Lady's Love?

sp.speaker: FLAVIA.
sp.l: Danger, most instant, she wou'd, now, impart,
E're Cassius, and his proud Confederates come—
Those Enemies of all her Hopes—and Gaesar!

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Go: tell her, Caesar dreads no Enemies,
But those, Her selt Afflictions teach to wound him.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Hear me, Thou! self-producing, dark, first Cause!
All-ruling! all-evading! aweful Power,
Whom, under various Names, blind worship seeks!
If, till compell'd, I drew the public Sword,
Sheath'd, in my Bosom, let the Guilty fall!
But, if brib'd Hopes, or partial Sense of Liberty,
Sovereign'd, a Senate, o'er a Nation, Slaves:
Then, Tyranny (assum'd, to bar a Tyrant)
Gave Rome five Hundred Kings—lest one shou'd reign.
If I must war—be edg'd my Sword, for Glory:
Better to hold, than bear tyrannic Sway:
Where but the Great are free—Reason's, a Slave,

div2.head: SCENE IV.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Caesar! my Life!—my Love!

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: my Soul's soft Care!
Thou tremblest!—Some new Vision has alarm'd Thee.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Heaven is alarm'd—for Virtue sleeps, in Danger.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Rest, from thy Dreams, by Day—thou dear Intruder!
Fears, and Affections, are for happier Hours:
War, and our Country's Cares, demand us, now.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Can you be deaf to Warnings, from the Gods?
Portia came, trembling, from a dreadful Dream,
That proves mine ominous.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: What has she dreamt?

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Frighted, she saw her Father's ent'ring Shadow
Glide thro' her Chamber, in a dusky Ray:
Stopping, it fix'd a pale, and empty Eye,
Spoke, in a thin, faint, death-denoting Voice,
And pierc'd her to the Soul.—Portia, Thou'rt mine,
Th' unbodied Phantom cry'd.—Brutus no more
Thy Lord—nor Caesar Rome's.—It said, and pass'd,
And melted into Air, and flow'd away.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: The night-born Tremblings of a timid Love,
Unstedfasted by Reason!

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Be it no more!—
Yet, see not these dire Men:—They find, and dread
Their Power's Destruction, in the Crown of Caesar.
Hence, have their plotting Fears, this Day, combin'd,
To blast thy Purpose—or, cut short thy Life.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Go, with thy medling Tenderness.—They come;
Anon, thou shalt be heard:

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: —One Word indulge me:
E're to the People's public Voice propos'd,
Plebian Votes permit this Crown to Caesar,
Hear a sad Secret, my touch'd Heart wou'd tell Thee.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Give thyself Peace.—I will.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: May all Rome's Gods,
In pity of her Fate, defend, and bless thee.

div2.stage: Exit Calphurnia, meeting Antony who bows to her, in passing.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Health, and a length of happy Days to Caesar!
Freedom, and Faction join, to crown him King.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Who wou'd be King of Faction, Antony?
Monarchs, by Freedom crown'd, reign Kings, indeed!

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Why checks that boding Sigh, the public Joy?
What is there, in the Course of worldly Dread,
That thy great Heart can Sigh for?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: —For a Friend

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: No Friend to Caesar needs a Sigh, in Rome.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Oh, Antony!—who wou'd not sigh, in Rome,
That thinks of her lost Virtues.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: —If there lives
One, who not hates Oppression, let him love
Rome, and her Virtues.—Both grown false, and hateful.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Hate not the Guilty, but the guilt, my Antony:
Ne're shall thy Soul expand, in public Love,
Till it can bear, and pardon, private Wrongs.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: When Slander stings us, what shou'd Sufferers do?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Invulnerably Faultless, shame Detraction.—
Why shou'd th'ungrounded Slanders of th' Unjust,
Provoke us, to deserve 'em?—Late, when here
We met, I told thee, Caesar, had a Son.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: If I forsake thy Race

sp.speaker: —Caesar
sp.l: swear nothing, Antony
Exacting Oaths, I must suspect Deceit:
And he, who trusts the doubted, cheats Himself.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: But who?—what Star of Rome is Caesar's—Son!

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Suppose it Brutus.—

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: —Every God renounce him!

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: What God renounces Excellence, in Man?

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Brutus is hard, and stern.—and, what is Man,
Who cannot weep for Man—and feel, for Nature?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Servilia was, in secret, vow'd my Wife,
When Cato, whose austere, and captious Virtue,
Repell'd even Virtue—if it cross'd his own
Jealous of our Assistance,—yet, undreaming,
How far one soft, stol'n, amo'rous Hour had borne us,
Snatch'd the succeeding Day, and, in my Absence,
Forc'd her, distracted, to a Brutus's Arms.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: What mean the wanton Powers, who license Chance,
To shame thee, with a Son, unlike, as Brutus!
Sedition, will not hear, the call of Blood:
Intractably morose, it shuts out Pity,
And starves Humanity, to cherish Pride.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Time, that transforms us all, shall win back Brutus.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Time's Comqueror might reclaim him.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: How!—To whom speak'st thou this?

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: —To Man.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: —Be one.
And, when thou speak'st again—speak, to the Father.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: If I offended—Caesar can be partial.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: No.—For, I see thee honest, through thy Error.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: I thought, Revenge of Wrongs was right of Nature.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Men think but to the Limits of their Minds.
For me—despising Wrongs, I shun Severity.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Yet, sure! Allenvied Greatness, wou'd be safe.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Greatness is safest, when it dares forgive.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Rome hates your Power.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Then, she shall love my Mercy.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: I can but wish thee bless'd:—And, still, serve on.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Come, thou shalt aid me.—Thou hast lent thy Arm
To conquer Nations for me:—Conquer Brutus:
Teach him, that noblest Courage shuns to hate:
Charm him, to taste the Power of gentle Sway;
New humanize his Heart, to thy soft Model,
And graft Politeness on his Savage Virtue.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: When Caesar bids—his Antony obeys:
Had Brutus been my Son—I, too, had hop'd.

sp.speaker: CURIO.
sp.l: Caesar!—th' expected Lords'

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Admit 'em, Curio.

div2.head: SCENE VI.
div2.stage: Caesar, seated: Antony, Brutus, Cassius, Cimber, Decimus, Casca, Cinna, Marcellus, advancing to their Seats.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Health to the Jealous for their Country's Freedom;
Caesar's Distrusters, welcome!—Cimber! Decimus!
This Day, the Senate sits: quick, therefore, teach me
The previous Purpose of your offer'd Zeal.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Rome dreads to lose her Caesar, in a King.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: What wou'd you do with this fam'd Sybil's Prophesy?
How check the public Terror?—Must I march
With trembling Legions, unsustain'd at Heart,
And desperate, from Defect of, but a Name?
By Oracles fore-doom'd for Parthia's Fall?
Cassius, you smile.—The Great should judge the Great:
For, never mean Man's Thoughts out-stretch'd his Feeling:
Speak, Brutus—were your Choice your General's Leader,
What wou'd you wish him called?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Rome call'd him—Consul.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Rome did so—but, when superstitious Dread
Of hostile Arms has damp'd a Nation's Fire,
Changes, which tend to raise dejected Hope,
Are Wisdom.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Wisdom has its Fears.—

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: —Speak boldly:
Attentive, even from Foes, to borrow Benefit,
I court Suspicion's Gall, to aid my Judgment,
With all th' instructive Doubts of Men, who hate me.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: No Foe has Caesar—but his Crown has many.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: King, was a Title, aweful, anicent, sacred.

sp.speaker: CIMBER.
sp.l: Plain Truth is a blunt Talker—never, rash Consul.
Never did Sylla, Marius, Pompey,—Never,
In all the Boldness of usurp'd Command,
Dare the shun'd Name—howe'er they grasp'd the Power:
Nor challenge kingly Style, in freeborn Rome.
But Liberty, perhaps, becomes too bold.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: True Liberty is bold, without Presumption:
And, without Flattery, gentle.—Cassius, be heard.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Caesar has sworn, to guard our ancient Rights;
Sworn, to uphold one sole Supreme—the Law:
Caesar unperjur'd, Rome can fear no King.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Malice, disguis'd in Counsel,—Keep it, Cassius:
Permitted Slander is a willing Tax,
That patient Power pays, to the Rights of Liberty.

sp.speaker: DECIMUS.
sp.l: Be Caesar King—but, still, let Rome be free!

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: A plain Man's honest Prayer.—Brutus why dumb?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: I must be dumb, if neutral:—but, compell'd
To speak, disdain to speak, unlike a Roman:
What helps it to Rome's Friends, if Rome wears Fetters,
That Foes, in Asia, join, to drag her Chain?
Leave Parthea safely fierce:—Dangers remote
Touch but our Fears—Domestick Ones are felt.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Brutus! Thou err'st, undreaming it.—Thou, Cassius,
Art, knowingly, an unmisled Misleader:
Thy Passions fram'd the Pile:—good Decimus,
Marcellus, Cimber, and such live Materials,
Buttress thy factious Building:—'Tis in vain,
To reason with the Partial: Men, who call
Their own corrected Pride, the public Danger;
Else, I wou'd say, to Minds, that could reflect,
Be Freemen among Freemen.—hard Controul
Breaks a wrong'd People's Spirits, into Slaves,
Or, spur's 'em into Rebell's.—'Tis dishonest:
What Right have we to Freedom, not alike
The Property, ev'n of the Poorest Roman?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: When fed the lab'ring Ox, abreast the Lion?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: How venal is all Rome!—Her every Senator
Sold, to his Passion's Biddings.—Brutus is sold
To Pride,—to avarice, some:—These Envy draw;
Those Fear;—in Others, hopes of promis'd Power
Warp the Dependent Will, to crooked Reasonings;
Loose, as the Bribes, that bought 'em.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Are, sometimes, sold—where Hands retain their Liberty.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: True—Angry Cassius!—But, the Head, misguiding,
Hands will mistake the Mark, and wound Themselves.
How soon have you forgot Pharsalia's Field?

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Fortune decided, there:—At Rome, 'tis Law,

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Fortune decided strangely Caius Cassius!
If I, by having conquer'd, must obey,
And you, from being beaten, claim Command!

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Aften such sierce, unveil'd, presumtuous Menace,
Rome must forget, ferever, to obey,
Or Caesar, once, to pardon.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: —Cassius, it grieves me,
That Thou compell'st a Sentence, too severe,
Since Mercy serves but to excite Offence,
And Bounty spurs Ingratitude—be—safe:—
Sunk, to the Shelter of a wrong'd Man's Pity,
Too feeble to provoke.—Escape Revenge.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.l: Call it no Crime, to apprehend Distress!
If Liberty offends, and Truth grows Treason,
Thank Heaven, the most dejected Slave, on Earth,
Holds Priviledge to die.—But Caesar frowns!
Note it, attentive Gods! and wake, for Freedom!
Imperial Caesar frowns!—Rome's Master frowns—
That Opposition speaks uncourtly Truth.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: No more.—The Rest, when in full Senate, met:—
Till then, farewell.—
—Stay Consul,—Brutus—stay.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.stage: —after a long Look, fix'd carnestly upon Brutus,
sp.l: Maxims, inhumam, fierce, and blind, like Thine,
Disgrace a Freeman's Name.
—Stay, I command Thee;
Return, rash Man—and know—'tis Caesar, calls.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: All my adhering Heart feels Caesar, King,
Leave but Rome's Senate free, devoted Brutus
Shall rest thy willing Slave.—

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Proud, as Thou art
Of Liberty, thou hast not learnt, that Freedom,
Beyond all Yokes, hates, most, this Yoke of Prejudice,
That makes Men Siaves, at Soul.—THINK freely, Brutus
And let us argue, like unbiass'd Romans:
Thou talk'st of Rights—Rome's Rights:—are not the People
The assembled People; ROME? Is not Law Theirs?
Counsel, that, not complied with, would compell,
Turns Law to Tyranny.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Shall Tumult reign?
Shall high-born Senates serve, and Groundlings govern?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: No.—Mark the Senate's Bounds—and mark the People's:
Foresight, and Guardian Care, and weigh'd Advice.
Debated Means, and Remedies propos'd,
These and these only, are the SENATE's Rights:
Propounded Laws accepted, or refus'd,
This is the PEOPLE's Claim: and both are Rome.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Thanks to the Gods, Rome boasts some Patriots, still.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Yes—grasping Hopes undue and check'd of Aim,
Patriots, in Aid of Vengeance! they combine,
To clog the Wheels, they can no longer guide:
Hiding low-self, behind the Public Cause,
They Murmur, till they purchase private Ease,
Then, License General Pain, to curse Mankind.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Held not the Senate Scale most Weight, in Rome?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Rome felt it, Brutus—till my Arms relive'd her.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: He, who, by Arms, rules Freemen, teaches Slaves—
By Arms, to rule that Ruler.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Trust a try'd Sword.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Curse its bold Use—in any Hand, but Caesar's,
When, to the vulgar Herd, it levels Nobles,
Born, to be Great—and mixes Hinds with Consuls.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Born did'st thou say?—mark, how thy partial Pride,
Barring the Gates of Hope, wou'd shut out Merit!
No Man was ever Born, but form'd to Greatness:
Who, but aspiring—Hinds—were—Rome's first Fathers?
Unvulgar Spirit rais'd their Deeds to Fame,
And, thence, unvulgar Reverence mark'd 'em Noble.
—But, in our Hands, diminish'd Honour Shrinks
To bare Degree,—and shames the Rights of Rank.
Heaven!—what a difference 'twixt Old Rome, and Ours?
Our first fam'd Ancestors gave worth—to Blood:—
We, from a worthless Birth, wou'd steal Distinction.
Pensions, with us, take Place:—with them, 'twas Virtue.
Our Av'rice Plunders Friends: Their conquering Bounty
Took nothing, ev'n from Foes—but Power of Insult.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Grant us less worthy; still Their Claims are Ours:
And Sons, who basely quit their Father's Rights,
Deserve to live, like Slaves—or die, like Traitors.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Fie!—let us Blush, to name our Father's Right's,
Who leave their Claim to Honesty, forgot!

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Oft, in sunk States, when Power presumes, on Vice,
New Crimes call out new Virtues.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Rome's new Virtues
Match her new Maxims: Mark their Grandeur, Brutus
Active, in other's Industry, we build,—
Race, Game, Dress, Dance, Feast, and drink deep, for Glory:
Ours are the Tastes of Life: Let humbler States
Learn its lean Duties:—We, to lighten Joy,
Have, elegantly painless! cast off Care:—
Hunger, and Thirst, and loose Desires—anticipate:
Posponing nothing—but Thought, Fame, and Justice.
Vallies we teach to rise: O'er levell'd Hills
Stretch the tir'd Sight:—But, inward turn no Eye:
Ourselves the darkest Part of our own Prospect.
Well say they, Rome is chang'd.—'Tis chang'd, indeed!
Women are chang'd to Men,—and Men to Women.
Anger has chang'd its Mark:—Roman's shock Roman's,
Yet, tame to Parthian Insults, hold back Vengeance,
That Robbers may have Rest,—and Bribery Leisure.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: To Sons of Faction, screen'd but by Rome's Crimes,
Why name we Roman Virtues?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: —On Thy Voice
Dwells Eloquence, that make ev'n Error charming,
O, too persuasive Caesar!—But Thou, Antony,
Shalt know, that, when fall'n Rome's degenerate Consuls
Live,—a King's Slaves,—Brutus shall die—a Roman.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Now, Caesar! what deserve such Romans?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: —Freedom.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: They are too free, who treat their Friends, with Insult,

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: If Man were plac'd above the Reach of Insult.
To Pardon, were no Virtue:—Think, warm Antony,
What Mercy is—'Tis daring to be wrong'd,
Yet, unprovok'd by Pride, persist in Pity.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Power, that endures Contempt, invites Rebellion,

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Dream not, that Moderation weakens Power:
The heart-felt Sovereign smiles, at Faction's Rage;
And those malignant Men, who hate unjustly,
We punish most, when we are most belov'd.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: What Prince, who was not fear'd, was, eyer, safe?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Only, in War, he shoud be fear'd.—In Peace, be honour'd Antony.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Even Self-defence requires, at least, that bloody Cassius fall.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Why shou'd I strike the Weak, who cannot wound me▪

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Punish the guilty Will, that dar'd imagine.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: So Minions teach tame Kings, to merit Hate.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Where Kings suspect,—preventing, they secure.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Scorn to suspect, where thou woud'st scorn to fear.
Nor waste, on ev'ry slight and weak Offence,
The Dignity of Vengeance.—I will, anon,
Trust Brutus with his Birth: Nature must move him.
If not—I leave him to the Gods, and Time.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Shall he oppose, yet, wear his Father's Crown?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Shou'd Life allot me Hope, to stretch Rome's Soul
To Latitude for Liberty—'twere more
Than Empire, to restore her.—If the Task,
Hard, and extensive, calls for lengthening Years,
While, in untimely Hour, I, distant, die,
Brutus, by this last Light, will judge my Purpose.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Long may the Gods, preserving Caesar's Life,
Protect his Purposes, from Care, not Caesar's.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Life has too short a Reach, for long Designs:
And, oft, the Fruit not ripe, the Tree declines:
No Help unneedful, Man shou'd all purfue,
Lest Time slide from him,—and his Hopes die, too.

div2.head: SCENE I.
div2.stage: A Room in Caesar's House. Two Chairs plac'd: Calphurnia, Flavia.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: GO, Flavia;—spread Enquiry through the Palace:
While I, prolonging Time, by every Art
Of apprehensive Love, hold Caesar, fix'd
In Conference, till slow Torbilius comes:
Fittest Reporter of his own sad Tale,
To force Belief, and fire reluctant Vengeance.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Where is this bosom Counseller of Caesar?

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Fly—find Torbilius:—when he comes, touch soft
My Silver Bell, that the known Sound may war me.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Tis past, Calphurnia.—The try'd Faction's hatred
Repell'd obtruded Candor.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Shun thy Forgiveness?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Men, of contracted Views, distrust kind Meanings;
For, no Heart credits, what it cannot feel.
What frightful Story has my Dreamer, now?

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: A sad, and dreadful Truth.-No Dream-No Doubting:
He, whose dire Property the Secret rests,
Guardian of Caesar's Life, demands his Ear.
For me—I cou'd but speak my Fears, and Follies.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Follies have Charms, when Fears, like thine, are follies:
Man may draw Profit, then, from Woman's Weakness:
And, in one tender Wife's mistaking Faith,
Find Recompence, for every Friend, that's false.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA
sp.l: Can there be Rest, in Danger?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Sure! There shou'd not:

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Why is Ambition, then, too hard for Peace?
Why, always busy, to be never blest,
Does restless Caesar sacrifice, unthank'd,
The Taste, the Quiet, the Serene, of Life,
For an ungrateful World, that hates his Bounty?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: 'Tis the great Mind's expected Pain, Calphurnia
To Labour for the Thankless:—He, who seeks
Reward in Ruling, makes Ambition Guilt:
And, living for Himself, disclaims Mankind.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Alas!—the Friend to All obliges none.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: 'Tis nobler to protect Mankind, than please.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Is it a Crime, when Virtue loves itself?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Princes shou'd widen self:—Their Power, and Heart,
Alike Receptive, must make room for All:
'Tis theirs, to Sigh, for every Sufferer's Woe;
Lend their own Joys, that others may be glad:
Think ev'en for unborn Ages; and transmit
Blessings unshar'd—and quiet, not their own.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Virtues, so rais-d, as these, but waste their Warmth,
And shine, unfelt, in Rome.—The Vulgar Eye
Sees, by its own low Level:—As Men act,
They judge: and, by corrupt Self-Interest weigh'd,
Goodness, like Heaven's, wou'd seem Self-Interest, too.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: No Matter.—Virtue Triumphs, by Neglect:
Vice, while it darkens, lends but Foil, to Brightness:
And juster Times, removing Slander's Veil,
Wrong'd Merit, after Death, is help'd to live.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Can present Pain be cur'd, by future Ease?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Who wou'd not, once, look dim, to shine, for ever?

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: How happy is it for a Wife, who loves,
When lowlier Prospects bound her Lord's Desires,
And Home-felt Quiet fills his peaceful Heart!
Why wou'd you be a King?—wait, till some King
Aspires, to be a Caesar:—Lend not Envy
New Props to lean against: This threat'ning Name
Beats on the Roman's unaccustom'd Ear,
Like a black Storm—and blasts the Hope of Liberty.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Never, henceforth, disturb thy gentle Breast,
With false Forebodings, from a regal Toy!
Know me above its Want:—beyond its Glory:
Given, tho' unheld, It meets the Parthian Prophesy;
Bids the rous'd Legion's superstitious Hearts
Resume lost Ardor:—and fure Victory's, Theirs.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Tho' Parthia fell, there's a Patrician Envy,
That, never quench'd, burns but with fiercer Blaze,
From each new Proof, that Old Injustice wrong'd thee:
Taink of those Midnight Haunters of my Fancy!
Think, how I saw thee bleed, at every Vein:
While, at each spouting Stream, a murderous Roman
Stain'd his extended Arm, and roar'd for Liberty.
Cassius!—stern Cassius!—
—Blast him, Heaven!—methinks,
I see him, there,—full, in my Eyes, he glares!
Pale, in the horrid Transport of his Vengeance;
And, dreadfully, enjoys the ghastly Scene!—
Oh! grant thyself, to live: Grant sad Calphurnia
That Prayer:—She begs it, but for Rome, and Nature.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Why wilt thou kneel?-What coud'st thou ask, in vain!

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Death—instant Death, to that malignant Cassius!

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Since thou were't first my Wife, I never saw thee
Cruel, till this strange Moment!—Dovelike gentle,
Healing Compassion sooth'd thy Heart, to Softness:
And, on thy sparkling Eye, sat weeping Mercy.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: 'Tis Mercy, to Mankind, to punish Villains.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Rise: and relieve me, from this new Distress.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: I will:—And thou shalt owe to Woman's Fear
A Safety, manly Confidence had lost Thee.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: How art thou heated, by an idle Dream,
To strike at fansied Guilt, with real Anger!

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: The Wife of Caesar wrongs not, even his Foes.
Flavia! Lucilia! here—who waits, without?
The Man, with whom I held Discourse, this Morning!
Bid him Re-enter.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Who!—What Man is this?

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Torbilius—the sow're Satirist:—Thy Enemy.—

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: No Enemy of mine—if Wit's his Friend.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Once, when condemn'd, for libelling my Caesar,
Thy all-permitting Mercy, not alone
Forgave—but, bad him claim distinguish'd Bounty;
Till Wit, misled, cou'd find the way to Judgment.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: I know him not:—What can'st thou hope, Calphurnid,
From these slight Men?—So bold, yet, blind of Soul,
That Wit, with them, supplies the Place of Virtue;
And, censuring other's Faults, absolves their own.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Staying, when Portia went, his trembling Gratitude.
Pray'd Audience, in a Cause, that touch'd the Life
Of threat'ned Caesar:—For the Rest, he comes:
Let his own Tongue retrace the horrid Tale.

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Hail, Caesar! more than Victor!—Common Conquerors
Vanquish but Power: Caesar subdues the Will.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Why dost thou flatter!—Stranger to my Passions,
Whence wou'd thy Skill presume, to judge my Virtue?
Take heed, thou sell'st not Praise, to purchase Scorn!
Encomium is a bold, and dange'rous Province!
It calls for Reason:—Slander asks but Rage:
Who drt Thou?—what is thy Pretence, in Rome?

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Touch'd by the Muse's Love, I, there, indulge
The tuneful Transports of Satiric Fire:
Rome is a fruitful Field, for Themes, like mine!
And Brutus, wit's kind Patron! loves my Verse.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Where Wit wants Patronage—a State wants Wisdom.
Keen, tho' the Darts, by angry Genious thrown,
The Wise can Guide 'em, while the Base Restrain:
Satire, in honest Hands, is Murmuring Virtue:
And He, who fears its Hiss, deserves its Sting.
Yet, tis a dangerous, and malignant, Good!
Tho' Freedom's Property, 'tis Faction's Spoil.
Where justly bold, 'tis Reason's manliest Impulse:
Where blindly virulent, 'tis Wit's Disease.
Think, and distinguish:—Are thy Censures weigh'd?
Dost thou Proportion Anger, to its Cause?

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Had I done that, I had not wrong'd thy Name:
I was not just:—For, I was Caesar's Foe.—
Can Caesar have forgot Torbilius Asper?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Why wonder'st thou at that?—For my own Sake,
My Friend imprints Remembrance;—but my Foe,
For His, shou'd be FORGOTTEN.

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Generous Caesar,
Forgetting me, forgets the Guilt, he pardon'd,
And Claims not his own Virtues!

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Roman! learn
To measure Truth, more justly:—Benefits,
From their Receiver only, claim Remembrance:
He, who bestows, and not forgets—resumes 'em

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Perish the Mem'ory, and the Man, together,
When I forget such Greatnef?—

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Spare thy Words:—
And hasten to disclose thy Thanks, in Action.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: What know'st Thou, that deserv'd Attention, here?

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Cassius, whose Love of Rome, is Hate of Caesar,
Lists an implicit Clan of warm Resenters:
Men, who, with dim Discernment, tracing Liberty,
Plunge headlong in Sedition.—Among these,
He stoop'd his active Bribe'ry, ev'n to me:
Courting my humble Aid, to influence Brutus,
Whose Name, and Power, might Mask the Face of Murder.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Whom would they Murder?

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: —Rome's last Hope, in Caesar.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Now, Caesar! now, am I an idle Dreamer?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Does Brutus know this Purpose?

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: —Yet he does not:
And Caesar, still, might guard the generous Heart
Of his belov'd: And save him, from the Vile.
All Flatter'y's full-try'd Power Unites, to shake him:
That done, the Tempter ply's his Master Engine;
Draws him, this Day, to meet the assassin Faction:
Then—but that Heaven defends Thee—join'd by Brutus,
Th' encourag'd Murde'rers strike:—not join'd forbear.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: If Caesar's Death must wait, till Brutus strikes,
His Life wou'd prove immortal!—Men, of Heat,
Like Cassius, torture their distemper'd Reason,
To Act their Passion's Impulse:—Brutus weighs
Desire's warm Pleas, in the cool Scale of Justice:
Finds Force, in Other's Claims, against Himself,
And loves the Virtue. that condemns him.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Go on, Torbilius!—Set, in Caesar's View,
What Cassius loves; and Point us out His Virtues.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: It shall not need:—He stands condemn'd, already.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: To what condemn'd?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Condemn'd to live, Calphurnia.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: What! and not tortur'd?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: —Pride's severest Rack
Is that sharp Mercy, which descends from Scorn.
Think it a Fault, to fear these choleric Praters:
Their hot, slight, Threat'nings waste themselves, in Slander;
And rail away Revenge, to gradual Peace:
But, there's a cold, slow, silent, patient Malice,
That carries Mischief with it!—Such a Soul,
As Brutus Acts by—had it Will, for Murder:
Cool, in its govern'd Hate, might call for Cruelty.—
What read'st Thou?

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: —Silent Summoners, to Murder
These Cassius Causes to be dropt, with Art,
Where Brutus must be sure to find, and read 'em.

sp.speaker: CALPHUREIA.
sp.l: What wiles has Malice!

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Poor, and petty, Crafts!
They want but my Regard, to lend 'em Weight.
Torbilius, meet 'em:—and, with strictest Note,
Mark, what Impression Cassius makes on Brutus.
All, Thou canst learn of That, be swift to bring me;
And trust the Claims of Gratitude, to Caesar.

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: The grateful make no Claims.—A mindful Debtor
Pays—not obliges:—Never met, in one,
The Poet, and the Miser:—The same Fire,
That sparkles, in his Fancy's native Blaze,
Glows, at his honest Heart; and burns out Baseness:
True Genious will not—cannot; stoop to Bribes:
And He, who sells his Passions, ne're had Wit,—
Or had it, for a Curse, unmix'd with Judgment.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: 'Tis nobly said;—and, with a warmth, that only
Suspected Virtue feels.—Henceforth, be mine:
On modest Merit, not to force Reward,
Were to degrade Supremacy.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Where meet They?

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: In the cool Grot, behind the Platan Grove:
There Brutus, oft alone, and oft with Friends,
Steals an unbusied Hour, for reasoning deeply:
Or, in free Mirth, dilates the slack'ning Soul.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA,
sp.l: What was the appointed Time?

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: The fatal Choice,
Yet doubtful, must depend alone on Brutus.
Some Three Hours, hence, I look to find 'em met,

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Go, good Tarbilius.—Wait within my Call:
For I shall Try thy Faith in Caesar's Cause.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: I am alarm'd. for Brutus!

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Doubt him not:

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Is he ambitious?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: No,—but he is vain.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Then, beyond Hope, he's lost.—Ambitious Men
Lead, and discern—but vain Ones follow, blind.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Thou hast contagious Power, in that Suspicion:
Great Minds, on some unguarded Quarter, weak,
Find their try'd Virtue, there, sublimely frail:
Were Cassius artful!—Had his Malice, Coldness,
—Cou'd he first praise,—and, then, attack, where warmest,
The Public-hearted Brutus.

sp.speaker: CALPURNIA.
sp.l: Nay he does;
'Tis from that Point, he levels all his Aim.—
Who knows not Brutus proud!—and Flattery's Art
Sets Pride at work, to sap her own Foundation:
And pull down Character, to build up Name.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Then, Cassius merits my regard:—and dies:
Light, in himself, he, yet, deserves but Scora:
Awak'ning Danger, in corrupted Brutus,
He makes his own rais'd Mischief worth Revenge.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: But, can I trust a Doubt, like this, to chance?
Th' unsure Conversion of a rash Man's Spleen?
Who knows, but, feigning Penitence, Torbilius
Courts you to Confidence, he would betsay?
No.—It shall ne'er be said, that Caesar's Wife
Left Caesar's Safety, to Another's Faith.
She, who, too lightly weighs a Husband's Danger,
Takes Arms, at Heart, against him.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Trust Torbillius,
He will deserve thy Faith:—Reflecting Minds,
By Gratitude once gain'd, relapse no more.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Thus will I sound his Purpose:—then, confide.—
Portia, this Morning, press'd a Visit, from me:
Oft, thro' her Garden's private Gate, unmark'd,
Ent'ring alone, that Grot, invites my Notice:
There, silently conceal'd, where Art-form'd Rocks
Lend jutting Umbrage to the cavy Screen,
I hear, what Cassius moves:—What Brutus yields:
This, if the Satrist dissuades:—he's false:
This, if he aids, Calphurnia judges Cassius:
And Life, or Death, be His, as Justice Dooms.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: In Love, and Anger, Woman's Will is deaf;
I know, thy gen'rous Purpose is too firm,
To let my Fears for Thee, forbid this Danger.
Yet, while, in Dread of mine, thou dar'st thus rashly,
Be it my Care to interpose, in Thine.
Curio, the Tribune, with a Guard, must wait Thee.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Their Number will detect me.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: No,—let Torbilius,
Singly, and slow, unnotic'd, introduce 'em;
Thro' the lone Postern, that adjoins the Grove.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Bless the kind Thought!—And now, shou'd Murder dare
One Glance, at thy dear Bosom, bloody Cassius
Shall, on the guilty Spot, that Moment die.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Spare thy disorder'd Heart.—Cassius is hasty!
But, Brutus shall with mild Reproof, reduce
The Madman's Rage, and shame him into Safety.
I dread to arm Thee.—Prejudice is rash.—

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Have I been subject, then, to rash Impressions?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Thy Reason, I cou'd trust—but not thy Anger:
Religion's Curb, in Heart's, like Thine, binds surest:
Swear, by some sacred Tye.—

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Hear me, whole Heaven!
By Rome's raiss'd Fate!—By her Forefather's God's!
By aweful Vesta's unexpiring Flame!
By Venus, Mother of thy Race, o' Caesar!
If Treason leaves out Time to reach thy Ear,
E're Danger catch thy Life—Cassius shall live,
To learn his Doom from Thee.—and 'scape my Vengance.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: See! the concurring Gods have sent Thee Curio!

sp.speaker: CURIO.
sp.l: Shouts, from impatient Crowds, demand a King;
And royal Caesar glads the Streets of Rome.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Curio!—Joy's flattering Sounds are loud Deceivers:—
Calphurnia's busy Fears have trac'd a Traitor,
Born to high Rank, and fam'd for Arms, and Envy.
Go, with due Strength; guard thou the Wife of Caesar:
And, if this Blank, that, now, conceals his Name,
Fill'd, by her Hand, points out the guilty Roman,
Weigh Caesar's Life, with His:—and be this Warrant
Thy Sword's Authority, to do me Right.

sp.speaker: CURIO.
sp.l: Where e're your Danger warrant's me to strike,
If Treason 'scape my Sword—let Flight in War,
Want—and eternal Infamy, Revenge,
The Cause of Caesar, on his Soldier's Name!

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Marc Antony return'd!

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Curio! thy Ear.—

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: All is prepar'd;—pale Cassius Looks, still paler:
And starts at every Shout, that Shakes the Forum:
Never, henceforth, let Noise be call'd Sedition:
Rome's public Mouth outroars a hundred Senates!
One loud Consent unites her grateful Tribes,
And Parthia's Fall takes Date, from Caesar's Crown.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Join'd Brutus, in that Voice.—

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: No Roman hop'd it:
Reserves, they know, must guard the Stoick's Gravity:
What sowre Solemnity of Look, like His,
Stoops a lost Smile, to grace Plebeian Lightness!
Men, who can laugh, as I do—jovial Thinkers!
Fram'd for their Ease, and born, to hate Affliction!
See Things, but as they are! void of the Wit,
That hunts for cover'd Anguish! long, sound Sleepers!
Dull, satisfied, glad Rogues! they trust their Senses,
Love their Friend's, best: and wish, but what they want.
Brutus is deep:—dives farther into Bliss—
Shakes his superior Brow, and pities Fools,
Who dare be happy, against Rules of Policy,

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Where coud'st thou find him, now?

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Immur'd, at Home,
Sagely despising his good Lords,—the People:—
And shutting Caesar's Triumph, from his Ear.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Take this Occasion, Antony, to visit him;
Bid his wish'd Presence grace thy publick Zeal!
If he declines it, sting him, to Resentment:
Watch, in that Warmth of Heart. what Thoughts escape him;
Sound the dark Depth of his Designs;—and tell him,
That to the Capitol, thou mean'st to bring me:
Rome's Crown, by Freemen given to guard their Liberty,

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: How noisy is that Nothing! All its Virtue
Dwells in its Sound:—It means but covered Tyranny.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Ever distinguishing Substances, from Sound:
There is in Liberty, what God's approve;
And only Men, like Gods, have Taste, to share.
There is in Liberty, what Pride perverts,
To serve Sedition, and perplex Command:
True Liberty leaves all Things free,—but Guilt;
And fetters every Thing,—but Art and Virtue.
False Liberty holds nothing bound, but Power,
And lets loose every Tye, that strengthens Law.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Caesar, in Science, as in Power, Supream,
Calls Lustre, out of Darkness!—But to Me,
What seems most strange, of Faction's strange Effects,
Is, that among those Crowds, she tempts to Mischeif,
I see good Men, belov'd for every Virtue!
Blindly misdrawn, to hate the peace they wish.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Boast fully blind, a Bigot's Proof is Trust;
Faultless in Purpose, yet—his Choice unjust!
Active, that erring Zeal may Truth invade,
Enthusiast Pride obtrudes her blund'ring Aid.
Fierce to the Field, keen Disputants she draws,
Implicit Props of some unreasoning Cause!
Th' absur'd Reformer Order overthrows,
And works up Discord—for the World's Repose!
Jealous of Enemies, disquiets Friends,
Groans, without Wound; and without Fruit, contends,
Wildly sincere! unprevalently strong!
Struggling for Right—and introducing Wrong:

div2.head: SCENE I.
div2.stage: A Grand Apartment in the House of Brutus.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: URGE it no more—I am fix'd.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Think wiselier Brutus

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Consul! when bold Oppression grapples Law,
Men, who protect the Oppressor, stab the State.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Men, who so roughly dare Mischarge their Lord,
Pretending Liberty, pursue but Pride.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Caesar, however rais'd, is less than Lord.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Caesar however wrong'd, is more than Friend:
Even Gratitude has made Respect, a Duty:
Present, or absent Thou—the Tribes will crown him.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Crown? whom?

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: One, whom if Brutus knew but rightly,

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: I fear I do!

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: No—if you did, you'd tremble.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: I have already, trembled Antony!
Trembled—to hear a Roman tempt a Roman,
And dare corrupt a Patrsot, yet unsold!

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Corrupt, I wou'd not.—All I wou'd, I dare.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: The basely bold shou'd learn, to dread the Just.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: When Brutus bids me dread—I hear and Smile.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Smile on your King: Flattery was made for Thrones.
The rough, wrong'd Roman frowns, with honest scorn.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Brutus, I rev'erence Firmness; but despise
Th' Hypocrisy of Envy! I have a heart,
That being human, feels for humankind.
I tow're not to the Gods:—Virtue, once rais'd
Above Compassion, ceases to be Virtue:
Aiming at more than Man, thou sink'st to less.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: I wou'd be less than King; and more than Slave.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Farewell:—rash Zealots blindly grow unjust;
And Pride inflexible,, and deaf, as Thine,
Professing Virtue, make's ev'n Virtue hateful.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.l: Heaven! what a Change in Rome!—breathe these her Soul
Oh! griev'd Quirinus! what Reproach wero Thine,
Did not thy fellow Gods disdain to note us!
Rome has no Remnant, now, of Roman Greatness:
Sold, or seduced, we give up Claim by Claim,
Till even our Virtues are engros'd by Caesar!
O, Souls of long lost Glory! Fabii! Decii
O, all ye Pompey's! Scipio's! Cato's! hear me!
Re-kindle, in my Breast, your patriot Lights:
And live, once more in Brutus!—fill this Heart,
With Caesar's Fire—but, let it flame, for Rome.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Torbilius! Thou intrud'st on my Retirement:
The Muse, and my sad Heart are, now, not social,

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Cassius approaches.—There's a Name, indeed,
Unsocial!—Every Muse wou'd start, to hear it.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Thou wrong'st him.—Cassius is a noble Roman.

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: There is a Jaundice, in thy Judgment, Brutus,
That lends him Golden Colour, from thy own:
I know him, to the Soul.—Have sounded all
The Shallows of his Envy;—and I cou'd,
But that an Oath, injoin'd, has bound my Tongue,
Convince thee, that he dares assault thy Honour;
And plots, to blast thee to the World, for ever.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Who bound thee, by such Oath?

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Calphurnia's Piety.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: What had Calphurnia's Piety to do
With Plots? and Oaths? and Secrecy? and Brutus?

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Earnest, herself, to warn endanger'd Brutus
With Consequence, she fear'd, my Words might lose,
She claims your instant Ear:—Be swift—incline it.
Shun the too near Approach of Cassius, hither:
And, hast'ning to the House of Caesar, weigh,
What her Wish forms, to guard thy Fame, and Virtue.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Thou art too bold, Torbilius:—Tell Calphurnia,
I, best, myself, defend my Honour's Claims:
And grasp, too hard, to need a Woman's Aiding.
Torbilius!—Rome has lost thee.—Caesar's Bounties
Have brib'd thy Gratitude, to slander Honesty.

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Ill am I known, where, most, my Heart lies open,
If, after all my rash Contempts of Power,
Brutus can doubt me Venal:—Yet, doubt on:
No undeserv'd Reproach adheres to Virtue.
No Matter what bold Slander wounds Torbilius,
Where he, who Wrongs him, has the Rights of Friendship.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: I will not see Calphurnia.

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Oh! revoke those fatal Words, lest

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: By the Gods! I will not; till Cassius, and his Friends have, first, been heard.

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Cassius is Caesar's Enemy.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: But I am Brutus;- and thou know'st me Caesar's Friend.
Let that Truth, known, content thee.

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: —No.—It cannot:
Brutus not fearing, I must fear for Brutus.
Greatness of Soul, confiding in itself,
Exposes an unguarded Side, to Baseness.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: What woud'st thou lead me to?

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: To one kind Promise:
I urge it but to save thee.—I conjure thee;
By every Claim of long, untir'd Adherence!
By every Recompence, thou ow'st my Dangers!
By every grateful Sense of every Duty!
Love, Friendship, Reverence, Faith, Advice, and Service!
Promise, whatever dire Result the Gods
Permit,—for Cassius comes on no light Errand!
Previous to any Deed, thy will may purpose,
To hear my Thoughts:—Intrust me with thy own:
And teach my willing Hand, and Heart, to aid thee.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: I see the strangely mov'd:—I will, by Heaven!
Intrust thee, unreserv'd, and seek thy Counsel.

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Bark on, ye Dogs of envy! Bark, in vain:
Brutus is Safe, and Spotless

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: —Caesar's Graces.
Win every Heart! and no Corruption's Power
Out-bribes the native Sweetness of his Pity.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Hail! death-devoted Brutus! Romes last Friend!

sp.speaker: DECIMUS.
sp.l: Guardian, in vain, of our expiring Liberty!

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Caesar, To-morrow, marches hence, a King.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: What are Rome's Prospects, then?

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Taxes, and Chains.
Brutus, farewell, for ever
—Life grows Shameful,
Where Freedom is resign'd, and Man's a Slave.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Can Cassius feel Despair?

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: When Rome Despairs.

sp.speaker: DECIMUS.
sp.l: When even her Soul—her Brutus!—Breaths for Caesar▪

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: No Force on Earth, but our unshaken Hearts
Held back this bold Invader.

sp.speaker: DECIMUS.
sp.l: Caesar's too Wise,
To spare our Lives, who live,—to shake his Throne.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Escaping us, he meets but Men:—Not Romans.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Oh! Honour, Virtue, and the Rights of Law!

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Tis past:—The Laws have been.—Honour, and Virtue
Are, now, the public Jest of penfion'd Parasites:
Who sell Submission, and receive back—Scorn.

sp.speaker: DECIMUS.
sp.l: Rome, and the World are fall'n!—'tis Caesar, All!

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: All, that Six Hundred bleeding Years have gain'd,
Thrown, at one Cast, to Caesar!—Why had Times,
Like these, a Brutus?—Grac'd with fruitless Virtues?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: If I have Virtues—Why shou'd They be Fruitless?

sp.speaker: CASSIUS
sp.l: Join every Power, above?—To bless that Question!

sp.speaker: DECIMUS.
sp.l: Hear yon licentios Noise!

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: —Curse the vile Sound!
'Tis Breath of Adulation! Rome's lost Gods
Expell'd!—And Insense paid to human Pride!

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Again!—Those Shouts are Insult.

sp.speaker: DECIMUS.
sp.l: —Cimber comes,
And, if I read him Rightly, in his Look,
Caesar's Attempts succeeds; for, see! he's Angry.

div2.head: SCENE V.
div2.stage: BRUTUS, CASSIUS, DECIMUS, CINNA, CASCA, CIMBER.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Tell us, what wou'd they?

sp.speaker: CIMBER.
sp.l: —Slavery, they wou'd

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Have we a King, in Rome?

sp.speaker: CIMBER.
sp.l: Have we a Freeman?

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: What call you Caesar?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Less, when he dares be more.

sp.speaker: CIMBER.
sp.l: Caesar high-seated,—Sovereign of the Slaves!
Shone, from the Capitol, as who wou'd say,
Make me a God, and Rome shall shake with Thunder:
Up, from Ten Thousand bribe-attesting Throats,
Flew purchas'd Gratulation: "Hail, Great Caesar!
"Rome's dread Avenger!—Fate of punish'd Parthia!
"Star of thy Country's Hope? And War's brave Guider!".
Timely, to cool this Madness, at its Height,
So Heaven decreed it!—In Stalks Antony;
Blast him, deaf Genius of devoted Rome!
A cushion'd Crown, and Scepter, sham'd his Hands:
Yet, was his venal Eye fix'd bold, on Caesar.
Down sunk, at once, the Tempest of Applause;
Hush'd, as a Coward, in his Midnight Bush,
The sick'ning People flatter'd into Silence;
He, 'midst a horrid Glare of wide-stretch'd Eyes,
Unheeding, on his Master's Brow, set, soft,
The regal Gew-gaw:—Then, with abject Knee,
Bent, for inflructive Homage,—be a KING,
He cry'd—and reign o'er Rome, that rules the World,
Caesar, mean while, who watch'd the public Eye,
And read Reluctance, Grief, and Terror, there;
Starting indignant with well-acted Scorn,
Hurl'd, from his Front, the uninclining Toy;
And cry'd—"I am not King, my Friend—but Caesar.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: O, Truth!—Beyond all Pride of kingly Greatness!

sp.speaker: CIMBER.
sp.l: Then, general Joy new-voic'd the gaping Press;
And shook the distant Roofs, with loud Concurrence;
Even Antony, then, blush'd.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: —And did not Caesar?

sp.speaker: CIMBER.
sp.l: Caesar smil'd sweet Contempt:—And then, again,
Th' unfeeling Fools, more charm'd, renew'd their Shouting:
I laugh'd, aloud: to mark him thanking Rome,
For finding Virtues in him, which he had not!
At length, disdainful of the hard Constraint,
Parting, he frown'd Sincerity.—The Rest
You'l learn, when I do.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: What means That?

sp.speaker: CIMBER.
sp.l: —Anon,
The Senate sits.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: CIMBER.
sp.l: Why then, Six Hours
May pass, betwixt his pushing back the Crown,
And our exacted Votes, to bid him take it.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Holds he that Hope?

sp.speaker: DECIMUS.
sp.l: Yes: And who helps us?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Death is, indeed, the Slave's last Hope:—but, he,
Who dares embrace that Help, might find a better.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: While my doom'd Country had a Gasp for Life,
I struggled on, to live:—Now, World, farewell!
No God sustain'd me, to support the State:
But, to die, with it, still, is left to Freedom.
To Heaven's imperial Rome, from ours, I go;
There, no bold Caesar sways:—There Pompey serves!
No Roman, there, need blush to owne a Master:
Where even a Cato finds, and fears, a Lord!
These will I follow, thus.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: —Follow we none:
'Tis ours, to lend, not borrow, brave Example.
'Tis ours, to stem the Tide of a bad World,
And justify to Time the Roman Greatness.
Much is to Anger due—but more to Rome.
Cato had died, unblam'd—first, killing Caesar;
But, turning on himself, his erring Sword,
He fell, unjustly:—For, he punish'd Innocence.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: What can we, in a World, despairing, round us?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: See! What the Friends of Liberty expect!
See! What they hope from Romans!

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: This Reproach
I, too, have met with:—And 'twas hard to bear!

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Cassius!—'twas harder, far,—to have deserv'd it.

sp.speaker: CIMBER.
sp.l: Good Talkers might attract a Gown-man's Praise:
And had Time Ears—fine Words were Marks of Wisdom:
But lose this Day, no Orator, in Rome,
Must be admir'd, but Caesar.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: —E're this Day
Yet passes,—Twenty Tyrant's Fortunate,
As ours—but never Greatness equall'd Caesar!
Might expiate, with their Lives, their bold Ambition.

sp.speaker: CIMBER.
sp.l: Ay! That's a Flower of Speech, my Rhetoric reaches!

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Rome lives again! She breath'd, in that rais'd Voice!
And Brutus has receiv'd her.—

sp.speaker: DECIMUS.
sp.l: —Fatal Name
To Tyrants!—Brutus, to assert his Race,
Speaks the dire Duty, which We dar'd but think.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: My Friend has reconcil'd me to myself;—
If there is future Glory due to Cassius,
Brutus bestows it, all—BRUTUS! and ROME!
Flow mix'd, ye reverend Names! down Time's dark Stream!
By Ages emulating Ages, bless'd!
Decimus! Cinna! Casca! Patriot's! Roman's!
Join your Sword's Aid: Obey this gener'ous Leader.
Live to approve, and to support his Vengeance;
And drive Dejection from the Heart of Virtue,

sp.speaker: CIMBER.
sp.l: All Rome will think, and Act, with Roman Brutus.

sp.speaker: DECIMUS.
sp.l: Born the Sustainers of patrician Honour,
Senates, despis'd, wou'd fall with double Shame,
Surviv'd, by their Despiser.—

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: —See a List,
Shinning with Names, of Rome's distinguish'd Sons!
Associates, All, to strike one Glorious Blow!

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Soft, Cassius!—have a Care! nor arm Revenge
Too Strongly:—lest it look, perhaps, like Baseness.
One were enough, to bid a Tyrant die,
Who dar'd Himself, die with him.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Roman's numberless
Stand, now prepar'd for Summons.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Summon none:
Shou'd they be sold to Caesar, they're untrusty:—
And, if they fear him, heartless.—

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Such a Tongue,
As Cicero's.

sp.speaker: CIMBER.
sp.l: No.—let us list no Praters;
These Speechmen of the Senate range but Periods:
Tropes are their Javelins:—Climax forms their Ranks:
And, when they charge, 'tis with some smart Harangue.
Twill be Renown enough, for these Tongue—Cohorts,
To praise our Bravery, when it meets Success:
Or, if it fails, teach pliant Law to teize us.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Enough!- then, Caesar finds us, in the Senate.—

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: There, be it lawful, O, immortal Guiders!
To consecrate this Sword, that, once, was Cato's,
To Cato's Death, reveng'd! and murder'd Pompey's.

div2.stage: All the Conspitators draw their Swords.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Now, I will live.—Life, now, becomes a Roman.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: No.—Let no vain false Hope of Life deceive ye:
Know—yet despise, your Danger.—Caesar's Friends
Crowd his tame Senate:—Ardent, All! and try'd,
In Service of their Master, while the People,
The suffe'ring People! pleas'd at once, and wretched!
Doat on the Tyrant's Heart, whose Hand they fear!
Think, too, tis CAESAR, we presume to wound:
Caesar! who aw'd an Army, with his Frown!
Our Death, in the Attempt, is fix'd as Fate:
But, what a Death!—How to be wish'd, and envied!
Dying, that unborn Rome may live, in Liberty!

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: How will our Deaths endear yon aweful Capitol!
That Seat of our Oppression, doom'd by Heaven,
The Scene of our Revenge!

sp.speaker: DECIMUS.
sp.l: —But, shou'd the People—

sp.speaker: CIMBER.
sp.l: Why let the People prate:—So People will—
Bless the Light Murmurings of their hungry Love!
Poor Gnats! They know, tis Summer, now, with Caesar:
Cloud but his Sunshine—all their Buzzing ceases.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Kneel, gener'ous Friends: They kneel, Brutus continues standing. Raise your Right Hands, to Heaven;
Swear—by the all-dreaded Powers, to wait my Call:
Nor, till I sound him, touch the Life of Caesar.—All the Conspirators.
We swear.—

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: —But shou'd he—(some kind God restrain him!)
Force my afflicted Hand, to point the Way.—
Then,—by that thin, pale, Flight of Roman Ghosts,
Whose hov'ring Forms skim o'er th' unburied Bones,
Which the wan Moon sees whit'ning twelve lost Fields!
Their Murd'rer, if he Reigns, in Rome. All shall die!

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Brutus, kneel with us.—Rome exempts no Knee:

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Blast, Heaven! The Man, who spares a Tyrant's Life!
Be he Son, Patron, Brother, Friend, or—Father!

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Or Father?—Cassius!

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Son, Friend, Father, Brother:
Tyrants can Claim no Kindred: They renounce
All social Ties:—And hate a hating World.
The expanding Soul, that swells a Roman Breast.
Stretch'd beyond Rights of Blood, attones 'em, All,
By Virtue, Glory, Liberty, and Law.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Be it, then, SWORN.— All—By Earth, and Heaven, we swear.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Soul-shaking Oath!—tis past, and, from this Moment,
sp.stage: Rise and put up their Swords.
sp.l: No Man has Parent, Child, or Friend—but Rome,
If there, among us, shrinks one recreant Slave,
Curse him, ye Gods! For every Guilt of Caesar!
And never let his Race know Comfort, more.
Hark! the confirming Powers approve my Curse—
Or, testify Dislike, in Peals of Thunder!

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Let 'em call on: The Brave, they know, are ready,

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: We meet, then, at the Capitol.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: —Haste, Decimus—
With heedful Caution, Summon each great Name,
That gilds our Glorious List:—previous, we meet,
(Immortal Brutus!) in thy aweful Grot.
There, shalt thou fan their Fire; confirm their Hearts:
Unite their Purpose, and instruct their Hands:
That one concurring Spirit may direct,
And no Confusion Rise, to blast our Vengeance.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: 'Tis dreadful!—But, 'tis necessary:—Mark!
When you pale Sun, that, with receding Ray,
Starts from our notic'd Purpose!—When that Sun,
Slow-measuring, sheds an Hour—This private Key
Admits you, thro' the Grove:—Be punctual All.
sp.stage: Gives Cassius a Key, then, advances to a Statue of Cato.
sp.l: Cato! Lost Soul of Freedom! Witness forme!
Here, I divest my Heart of Love, Grief, Pity,
Of every tender call of pleading Nature,
That moves too soft a Pang.
—Again!—'Tis Strange!
Why hangs this infelt Weight, upon my Purpose?
Can it be terrible.—To die for Rome!
What has he left to fear, who saves his Country!

sp.speaker: MARCELLUS.
sp.l: Break off—or, be prevented:—Caesar comes.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Now, let him die.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: —Avoid him, thro' that Gallery.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: With whom dost thou retire?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: —With banish'd Liberty.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Vain, honest Purposer! Made weak by Virtue!
Thou wrong'st the Friend of every Wish, thou form'st!
Cited by Antony, why cam'st thou not?
Or why, not coming, was Reproach thought needful?
With insolent Contempt of Power above thee?
Find'st thou Delight, in living to offend?
There's not a Name, in all thy private Friendships,
That is not mark'd, in public, as my Foe.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: When Foes to Caesar are the Friends of Rome,
May Heaven inspire his Will, to love their Counsel!

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Speak out:—The just Enjoy the Slanderer's Malice,
And weigh their Virtue's Force, by bad Men's Censure.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: All Men confess the Force of Caesar's Virtues:
Resistless Virtues!—They endear the Chains
Of a submitting World, that smiles, and suffers!

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Thou art, thyself, in Chains, and see'st it not;
Thou art that poorest of blind Slaves—a Tool!
Whose Bluntness works for Wills, that scorn thy Promptness.
So work'd they, once, on Pompey.—Weak well-meaner.
Driven, yet, too proud to follow!—Had he conquer'd,
His flexile Yoke had gall'd, both Men, and Laws:
Then, what had Brutus been?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: —Lord of one Dagger.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Fell mind!—And can there none be found, for Caesar?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Strike, first—and blast the distant Possibility!

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: No.—Brutus!—There's a Power forbids that Blow:
Read this, blind Wanderer!—Know thyself, and me.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Caesar, I die:—Punish'd by Heaven's just Hand,
At once, my Life forsakes me, and my Love.
Pity, when I am gone, and think of—Brutus:
The Life, you gave him [Starts] will deserve your Care.
Farewell!—And, for the Father, may the Gods,
To the Son's Heart, transfer the Mother's Love!
Servilia!—Heaven, Servilia!—wrote she this?
She did—and, if I wake, Rome sleeps forever.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: I had not thought, till my return from Parthia,
To trust thee with this Secret, of thy Birth:
But to protect Thee, from the Willes of Cassius,
I claim Thee, and Precipitate my Purpose.
sp.stage: Offers to embrace him, who starts back

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Rome! Virtue! Nature!

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Nature! young Man, call it
By its sincerer Titles? call it Pride,
Self-soothing.—Hurl your Bolts, ye Gods! at Faction!
Faction!—that finds a Power to blot out Nature!

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Spare an astonished Wretch, who lives too long.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Is there, who fears to be the Son of Caesar?
Wretch, say'st thou?—to be born the World's next Heir,
And reap the Laurels of a Hundred Victories?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Oh, Caesar!—

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Lab'ring with a Will to speak,
Some infelt Horror checks thy rising Accents.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Speak like my Son.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Wou'd I were dead.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Sounds Death more soft than Son?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Such if I am,
Brutus, unbow'd to Kings, may kneel to Caesar.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: On.—

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: —Kill me;—or, forbear to be a King.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Thy very Soul's a Rebel:—not alone
To Power, but ev'en to Blood:—unatural Traitor!
Rise, and repent:—and, when thou think'st, like Man,
Be own'd Rome's Son, and mine:—till then, be Brutus,

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Oh! stay.—I never can quit Claim to Caesar:
Hear, if a Father, with a father's Ear;
Or, judge with a Friend's Heart, and ease my Horror.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Leave me.—My Heart is Adamant:—Away;—
My Blood grows warm against thee: Dread thy danger.
Be gone—or, I shall catch Disdain, from Thine,
Till, conqu'ring Pity, to repel Presumption,
To punish Insolence, I push back Nature.
Caesar, at least, was born, to govern Brutus.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: He was—he was—but not to govern Rome.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Headstrong Enthusiast! Stubborness, like Thine,
Embroils Republicks; and makes Tyrants needful:
Go: join thy savage Friends: chase Fear from Faction:
Bid Guilt sleep safe, in my Contempt of Treachery:
Their Conqueror stands subdued, by his own Mercy:
—Yet bid their Blindness learn, when Claims contend,
And Rights invaded rouse resenting Realms,
'Tis Fierceness, in the Free, most, hazards Freedom.
And Liberty is lost to punish Pride.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Let me not leave him, tho' Despair has caught me:
But, following, sigh for Rome—and live for Caesar.
Why was I born to think, and be unbless'd,
To licence Reason, is to forfeit Rest:
He, who assumes Distinction, calls for Woe;
Peace is a Cottage Claim, and loves the Low.
Nor Shame, nor Trust, nor Envy, finds us, there!
Hearts, fill'd with Quiet, leave no Void, for Care.

div2.head: SCENE I.
div2.stage: A Grot in the Garden of Brutus.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA
sp.l: 'TIS near the appointed Hour:

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: I judge, tis past.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Then Heaven, that loves its Likeness, wake for Caesar,!

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: In this Out-Grot, they meet:—In that adjoining,
Curio has close conceal'd his chosen Guard,
Each Moment strength'ning, by admitted Files:
Hence vocal Windings, which pervade the Rock,
Swell whisp'ring Sounds to Loudness.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: How look'd Portia?

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Sad—till she heard your animating Name:
Then, like a Sun-beam, radiant thro' a Mist,
She smil'd away her Anguish.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: —At her Approach,
Leave me Torbilius.

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: —Who then guards you hence?

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: I mark'd th' impending Ivy, o'er the Arch—
Grieve, not tho' Pride repell'd thy honest Purpose,
Nor fear the endangering Fate of stubborn Brutus:
My Friendship, in alarming Portia's dread,
Will caution, and preserve him.—Go:—she's here.
sp.stage: [Exit Toroilius bowing to Portia, whom he meets ent'ring.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: This mournful Grot ne're touch'd my Taste till now:
But present Friends bring Sunshine to the Soul.
And Seats of Horror change to Scenes of Bliss.
'Twas fortunate, thou call'dst thy Portia, hither!
Brutus is sad to-day, and Purposes
Retirement, here, beneath this sullen Shade:
Our Presence will relieve him.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: —Stop him, Portia!
Let me not find him:—save my Eyes that Horror!

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Good Heaven!—what has he done?

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Stay not, to ask:
Even that lost Moment may be fatal to him.
Go; bid him guard his Ear from cruel Cassius:
Time will permit no more; go warn him—save him.—
If thou delay'st a Moment, Fate o'ertakes him;
And staying but, till Cassius comes—he dies.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Be clear in Pity to my beating Heart;
Brutus has been traduced.—He loaths all Falsehood▪

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Shunning the Falsehood loath'd, he may be safe.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: He comes.—Now, hear him justify his Fame,
From this foul Charge—and vindicate thy Goodness.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: No.—Tis thy Weight must shake his concious Soul.
Save his endanger'd Name, and bless my Notice.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: I cannot move:—forgive my trembling Knees,
My Heart restrains their Power.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Alas! I pity Thee:
Rest, and recall thy Spirits, and receive him.
Now, to my fatal Post.—

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: —Some dreadful Meaning!
And my too wakeful Fears confirm it just:
Cassius, of late, with warm, assiduous Art,
Flatters my Brutus, whom his Envy shun'd:
Cassius is wily, proud, malicious, bitter!
Burns, with ungovern'd Hate: and brooks not Caesar.
Associate Vice may taint the soundest Virtue:
And Honour bleeds, shou'd Caesar fall by Brutus!
Not that my patriot Heart disclaims the Roman!
I, who was born to Liberty's great Guardian,
By right of Nature, shun tyrannic Sway:
Yet Brutus—twice offending—twice forgiven,
Twice, forfeited to Caesar's Clemency,
His own lost rights to Justice:—shou'd he, then,
Quench the kind Light, he lives by, the rash Murderer
Kills his own Fame, and dies to every Virtue;

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Who call'd thee hither Portia?

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Rome's kind Gods.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: In Haste they summon'd, and, in Haste they left thee.
Was it, because they saw Calphurnia with thee?
And shun Society with Caesar's Friends?

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Ne're may the Gods forsake the Friends of Caesar,
Since Brutus more than all Men, such, by Gratitude,
Merits Protection from the Powers, who love it.—
Does Cassius move in Grots?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Why ask'st thou that?

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Romans, who meditate the Death of Caesar,
And owe him not their Lives, may mean no Murder.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Torbilius is a Traitor:—Rome is bought,
And all those guardian Gods, who lov'd her Liberty.
Forsake her, and support the Cause of Caesar.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Rome bought?—and Traitors?—If I watch thy Look:
Rage, and Despair, have dim'd thy Eyes with Anguish,
If I regard thy Language,—Death dwells, there,
And, like a Groan, at Midnight, frights my Fancy.
Stay I would ask.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Ask nothing;—'tis a Time
For Action:—keep thy Words for idler moments [is going.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Hark! tis thy Fate, that calls the.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: I have heard it:
Why woud'st thou thus restrain me? -thoughtless Portia!
Be wiser.—All the Lives of Rome's best Friends
Demand me! Theirs the Fate, that calls!—Away:—
Honour, and Oaths, and Death, and Glory—call me.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: By Heaven! you go not, till you first relieve me,
From this dark Torment, which your Words implant:
I'll know, what Friends? what Oaths?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Loosen thy Hold:
Nay, if thou stay'st me, my unwilling Strength
Must break ungently from this ill-tim'd Rashness.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Turn, Brutus! turn,—regard this silent Pleader?
If thou woud'st wish to spare the Breast of Portia,
Dread the determin'd Hand of Cato's Daughter.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: What wou'd thy Madness hint? what means that dagger▪

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.stage: Pointing a Dagger to her Breast.
sp.l: Stir, not a Step.—Thy first vain Start to seize me,
Plunges Deliverance to my rescued Heart,
Which unconfiding Brutus loves to torture.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: What would thy Soul-distracting Purpose frame?

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: The bloody Secret, thou conceal'st from Portia,
Thou shar'st, with every vulgar Friend of Rome.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Why woud'st thou bid me license future Scorn,
To haunt my hated Name?—Make me not faithless,
Lest Songs teach Times to come my Hearts fond weakness;
That, to a Woman's Tongue, resign'd a Secret,
Which sunk the World's last Hope;—and gave up Rome.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Where sleeps the Spirit of thy stern Forefather?
Whose awful Firmness, sculptur'd into Life,
Frowning thro' Stone, disclaims degenerate Rome!
Teach him, some God! that CATO call'd Me Daughter▪
Brutus believes me light, like vulgar Woman!
Oh!—'twas for this, the sorrowing Shade resought me;
Hinted Futurity, through mystic Night,
And shew'd me, Brutus wou'd be Mine—no more.
Find, in that dreadful Warning, how HE judg'd:
Feel, what he thought of his own Portia's Daring.
Trusting the Fortitude, he gave—HE knew,
That Cato's Daughter could not dread to hear
The worst, that Cato's Spirit dar'd to tell.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Generous, I know thou art;—But thou art Woman:
Secrets of State, and Blood, o'erload your Minds.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Tis the false Reasoning of a Sex, that wrongs us:
Why shou'd a Secret's weight o'erload the Heart
Of Portia—yet, disturb not that of Brutus?
All, thou can'st wish me, thou shalt find, I am:
All, thou can'st suffer, thou shalt feel, I dare.
Poorly, perhaps, thou think'st, the Fear of Wounds,
And Pain, and Sword's, and threat'ning Death, might shake me!
—Judge,—by this willing Blow—
sp.stage: Strikes the Dagger into her Left Arm, which Brutus, advancing swiftly, snatches from her.
sp.l: "—off—off—by Heaven
Thy Failure had transferr'd it to my Heart.
Learn, from this bleeding Proof, that,—when I shrink
from Thoughts of Death, I fear not for my own.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: What has thy Pride's ill-grounded Rashness done!
Oh! let me Mend that error of thy Hand:—
Bind up th' ungentle Wound, and call Aid to thee.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Never!—tho'Death divide us!—Never—never
Shall Portia veil this Mark, how Brutus lov'd her;
Till, to Redeem her Life, he trusts her Vertue.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Perish the Pride of such a dear-bought Fame,
As costs my widow'd Heart the Life of Portia!
—Read that dire List.
Till my Return conceal it:
And weigh those mighty Names, against ONE Caesar.

sp.speaker: PORTIA
sp.stage: Permitting Brutus to bind her Arm with his Handkerchief.
sp.l: Must Caesar die?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: —Twas sworn.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: —Did Brutus swear.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: He did:—A dreadful Oath!—ask what, hereafter▪
Bound to the Gods, those angry Souls of Rome.
Submitting to my Hand, the public Vengeance,
Kill Caesar, instant,—or permit his Life,
As Brutus warrants, or with-holds, the Blow.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Then, Caesar cannot die.—He pardoned Brutus.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Oh! I cou'd tell thee Wonders!—But the Help,
I fly to send thee.—and their forfeit Lives,
Whose Rashness I must warn, permit no more.
Portia, farewell:—If e're we meet again,
I will complain, of thy impatient Ardor,
And thou shalt justify the Heart of Brutus.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Live, Caesar! live, and reign!—Tho' Cato's Blood.
