Calls for Revenge;—and a whole People's Rights,
Usurp'd, absolve one bold Assumer's Fall;—
The Hand of Brutus must not stain Rome's Justice;
Nor, with detested Murder, pay back Mercy.
Heaven! what confederate Power! what Names, least likely,
Start from this dreadful Roll, and threaten Caesar!
—Wou'd I were still a Stranger to this Secret!
Yet, that unknown,—who had dissuaded Brutus?
Is he dissuaded?—let me weigh that Question.
Who knows but, while I speak, th' appointed Hour
Impends!—It DOES!—Farewell, he said—and left me!
Farewell!—then added—if again we meet!
IF!—Heaven! what meant that if?- tis plain he doubted,
Whether we ever were to meet, or No!

div2.head: SCENE VI.
div2.stage: To PORTIA, enter CALPHURNIA, with TORBILIUS, CURIO, and Soldiers.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Never, unhappy Portia!—Far divided
Be Innocence like Thine, from Guilt and Murder!
Teach thy reluctant Heart, to give up Brutus:
For never will thy Eyes behold him more.
sp.stage: Portia fix'd in Amazement, lets fall the Roll, which Torbilius takes up, looks into, and offers to Calphurnia.
sp.l: Let not the hated Scroll pollute my Touch!
Fly with it, hence—bear it, with Speed to Caesar:
Tell him, Torbilius! how the Gods have sav'd him:

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Happy, to miss thy Name, lov'd Brutus, here!
Well-vers'd in Caesar's Pity,—glad, I go.

div2.head: SCENE VII.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Oh!—

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Wife of Brutus!

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: —Chill'd to Stone, by Horror,
Kindly, thou wak'st me, with that powerful Name.
And my recov'ring Breath implores thy Mercy.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: The Wife of Caesar speaks: Absolve her Justice:
Had the too dreadul Danger been Calphurnia's,
Then, had my willing Pity met thy Prayer:
Sav'd, whom thou lov'st, and lost a Third vain Mercy,
But thou hast heard it! Brutus murders Caesar!
—Yes Cassius!—bloody Cassius!—I have wrong'd thee:
The Foe but wish'd Revenge:—The Friend resolv'd it.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: What does thy angry Virtue mean to do?

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: —Blast his vow'd Guilt, and force him to be safe.
Round, from the neighb'ring Grot, rush Caesar's friends,
Rapid for Interception:—If they find him,
Try thy wish'd Power: reclaim his Will, from Cassius,
Whom if his Fate has driven him, now, to join,
By all my Fear for Caesar's Life—he dies!

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Detain him, all ye Powers, who pity Woe!

sp.speaker: CURIO.
sp.l: Vain was our speed:—There is an Iron Door,
That, opening to a Vault, beneath these Rocks,
Leads toward th' Aemilian Baths:—'scap'd thro' that Passage,
E'ere now, he rises in the Shade of Rome.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: See! th' unhappy Sufferer faints!—support her:
sp.stage: To Curio, in a lower Voice.
sp.l: Mean Time, while slow-returning Sense forsakes
Her pitied Ear, whose Sighs my Soul deplores,
Curio!—The blank Commision, Caesar gave thee,
Claims, from my Hand, a Name, to guide thy Duty:
sp.stage: Receives the Table-Book, from Curio, writes in, and returns it to him.
sp.l: Brutus becomes the Void, with bloody Grace;
Take it, and know thy Hour.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Bless'd, ye kind Rocks!
Bless'd, be your guardian Echos! That have swell'd
Death's Murmurings to my Ear:—If my Strength fail not,
Home, on the Wings of Love, and Fear, I'll fly:
Brutus shall live; and every God shall guard him.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Restrain her, Curio!—The preventive Love,
This weeping Vertue bears her sentenc'd Lord,
Wou'd warm him from the Fate, his Guilt compells.
Come—guide th' afflicted Trembler to my Palace.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: No.—Kill me, here:—Earth has no Place, so fit
For Portia's Death, as where her Brutus left her:
Art thou a Soldier? hear me:—All the Brave
Have Hearts to weep the Woe, their Hands have caus'd.
But Man is cruel.—Hear, Calphurnia!—Thou
Art Woman:—Thou art Caesar's tender Wife.
Measure another's Mis'ery, by thy own.
Pause but, to think thyself the Wife of Brutus;
'Twill plead my Cause, and force thee to forgive.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Cou'd Portia so forgive the sought, sworn, Death
Of Him, beyond whose Life she shuns to live?
Knock at thy own Heart's Door, and find mine justified:
Yet, bleeds my social Soul, and feels thy Fate;
Poor, suffering Excellence! And wretch, unguilty!

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Oh! I can never by a Wretch, by Thee!
I am thy Friend:- Dwell on that Thought, Calphurnia:
Even, when the CRADLE claim'd me, I was Thine:
Sorrows, and Pains, must come:—They come to All,
But, sure! they shou'd not come from those, we love.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA
sp.l: They cannot come from Love:-They may from Justice.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Let Foes, and Strangers be, severely Just:
Friendship declines to punish, tho' 'tis wrong'd.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Think of the present Hour.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Think of the Past;
When pratling Childhood, yet, had learnt no Power,
To lisp its little Meanings, into Sense;
Stammering our untaught Instinct, Side by Side,
We wander'd, fearful of each other's Fall,
And tripp'd, and smil'd, and totter'd, into Love.
Scarce felt our rip'ning Years a Sense of Woe:
'Twas Foreign, all—for all, within, was Peace.
While the divided City, round us, glow'd
With cruel Discord, and domestic Rage;
Even, while our dearest Friends took different Sides,
And Civil Fury shook the partial Soul:
We, still superior, to a Nation's Hate!
Smil'd on—confided, mix'd embracing Minds;
And all our Contest was—which, most, shou'd Love.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Why woud'st thou, thus, recall past Hours of Joy?
Those were the sun-shine Days, of Mirth, and Peace.
Now, 'tis all win'try Darkness,—War, and Blood!

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Brutus is dear to Portia.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: —Not less dear
Is Godlike Caesar, to Calphurnia's Soul.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: If Brutus lives.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: —Caesar, he swore, must die.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Cruel Impatience! Not to hear Distress!

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Patient I heard, till he confess'd it sworn:
Heard, till he told thee,—each dire Murderer dar'd
Vow Caesar dead,—when Brutus Wills it done.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Brutus will not.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: —Away- 'twas Sworn, 'twas SWORN.
Hear that, all-judging Heaven! And think, by whom!
Ingratitude's a Guilt, that startles Nature,
And, with a Fury's Foulness, stains Mankind!
Constrain her, Curio!—Force her gently, on:

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Stay, Stay—I will be heard,—cruel Calphurnia!

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Alas! What woud'st thou say?

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: —Wou'd I cou'd tell!
Wou'd I were skill'd in Woe, to touch thy Pity!
Perhaps, I shou'd be Humbler?—Teach me, tell me.
Oh! I'm not stubborn.—If the Queen of Caesar,
Waits for the bended Knee; and, looking down
To suppliant Homage, tastes the Flatterer's Prayer:
See! Portia, prostrate on the Dust, implores thee,
See her Soul agoniz'd,—and ease her Terrors.
Grant him but Life! Spare his mistaking Virtue:
Banish him—far from Rome, and Power, and Caesar.
To unhous'd Seythia's bleakest Wilds, expose him:
Leave him one—one—but one! Sad, humble Shelter!
His Portia's aching Bosom!—Never—ah?—Never,
Will she forsake him!—Off, ye glittering Trifles!
Ye Toys! That help to blind unbless'd Distinction!
Come—in their Place—Despair! Affliction! Penitence!
Be these my Claims!—For these my Brutus shares in.
Shuddering, and bare, I'll trace th' unsheltry Desert
Tread the bleak Wilderness of Want, unsighing,
Unwishing Comfort, and content with Pain.
Sleepless, myself, I'll watch his weary Slumbers,
Feed his pale Fire, hang o'er his heedless Bosom:
Break ye rude Snow-drifts, which the Storm blows round him,
And love him into Taste of safe Distress.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Why will ye wound Compassion, by Delay?
The Sorrows of a suffering Friend, are Torture,
None, but a Devil, at once can cause, and bear.
Relieve me, and, with tenderest Force, obey.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Reverence, ye Slaves of Power! The Race of Cato:
His unsubmitting Soul survives, in mine:
And swells against Compulsion.
—Dare not think,
I dread to die.—But know, that Portia's Death
Shall be the Choice of Portia.
sp.stage: At a Signal from Calphurnia, they seize her Hands.
sp.l: —Hope, as soon,
To claim impassive Spirit!—High Disdain,
Resisting Insult, at a Thousand Doors,
Can let out Life, and laugh at vain Restraint!
I will, with stubborn Pain, imprison Breath,
And burst, indignant, from a World, that holds me.
I will, on stony Pavements, hard and cold,
As deaf Calphurnia! Dash my dizzy Brain:
I'll swallow Fire:—Rend, with impatient Teeth,
This suffering Flesh, and plunge from hated Light:
Unhand me, Torturers! Murderers!—Help! HELP!
I will extend my Voice, if Brutns hears not,
Till the forgetful Gods are rous'd to Justice!

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Where are you? say! Whence flow'd that suffering Sound?

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Blest be th' attentive Powers!—'Tis Cassius calls.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Haste, Cimber! Join Marcellus; guard the Postern:
Cross those arm'd Enter'ers, e're they reach the Grove:

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Save me, righteous Jove!

sp.speaker: CURIO.
sp.l: Scorn this new Terror. Think, whose conquering Fortune
Summons a Sword, untaught to wrong his Cause.

div2.stage: Exeunt Curio, and Soldiers, drawing their Swords.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Heaven guard my Caesar,

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Save my Brutus, Gods!

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Guard well those Priso'ners, while I—
Calphurnia, here!
Nay then, some Villian has betray'd our Cause.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Torbilius bears your listed Names to Caesar,
And Brutus, if you save him not, must die.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Freedom has Friends, in Heaven, too strong for Caesar;
No Note of Danger, ever, more shall reach
The Tyrant's watchful Ear:—Rome's vow'd Avenger's,
Now, at his Entrance to the insulted Senate,
Led on, by Liberty's returning Gods,
Shall, there, appease them, with his offer'd Blood.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Hold firm my frighted Heart! Tis but a Moment!
Suffering with Dignity, disgrace not Glory:
Ev'n, in this dreadful Turn, preserve thy Greatness
Nor let thy trembling Fears, alarm'd for Caesar,
Lose the Distinction, due to Caesar's Wife.
Portia! A Change, like this, might prompt weak Minds,
To justify Despair, and give up Virtue.
But I, who trust the Gods, with good Men's Safety,
Know, that, in Caesar's Triumphs, Heaven but guards
Th' assaulted Greatness, which, Itself, inspir'd:
Rising against Distress, Calphurnia smiles
At Traitor's Threats, and brightens from Eclipse.
Fearless, to persevere her Lord has taught her;
And, from meant Evil, force unwilling Good.
All, Thou must hope, when Caesar's cloudless Star
Meets, and shines through, and burns above this Tempest;
Is—that my Sentence may remain suspended,
Till the Dictator's never-wearied Mercy
Pours Penitence, on the touch'd Heart of Brutus.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Slow Blessings come too late, and bring new Curses:
This, but a Moment past, had sav'd us, Both:
Now, Portia rules not, here:—Tis angry Cassius:
The proud Conspirators possess my Gates,
And Brutus, absent, leaves me to their Power,
He flew, to warn those rash, discover'd, Romans:
But hasty Rage makes frustrate every Care.
—Yet, claim what e're my Weakness can:—Tis due
To kind Forgiveness of a Friend's first Fault:
To our past Wish's, and our present Fears:
For, ah! Who knows, what dire Events impend,
To blast eluded Hope, and make both wretched?
—Come, to my Chamber, let us sadly move,
Pensive, from Fear, and terrified for Love:
There, let us mourn Ambition's restless Rage,
And mutual Mise'ry mutual Help engage.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA,
sp.l: Warm, from my willing Heart, I join that Prayer,
Ne're may Ambition waste a good Man's Care!
Vain are his Hopes reluctant Foes to bless:
And still, the more his Toils, his Praise the less.

sp.speaker: CIMBER.
sp.l: Sure! Never Day ran back, like this, before!
So sweet a Dawn, so chang'd, at once to Tempest:

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Chang'd, like the Fate of Rome! Above, tis Sunshine:
Beneath, tis, all, due Darkness!—Senate's Power
Shall brighten, and plebeian Clouds ride low.
What hasty Footstep that?

sp.speaker: CIMBER.
sp.l: —'Tis Decimus!

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Alone! Why comes not Brutus?

sp.speaker: DECIMUS.
sp.l: —Near thy House
I met him hast'ning to suppend our Meeting:
And urg'd the general Cause, that claim'd his Presence.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: He shou'd not, yet, have heard of Portia's Danger,
Nor Caesar's Warrant, found.—

sp.speaker: DECIMUS.
sp.l: I told no more
Than that Torbilius, trusted with our Names,
Lodg'd 'em, in Caesar's Hand.—So, what, before,
Was common Glory, common Safety, now,
Demanded instant:—therefore, here we met,
No more to part, till Rome, or Caesar fall.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Heard he that, firmly?

sp.speaker: DECIMUS.
sp.l: He's at Hand, to join us.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Then Fate is Ours: And this proud Climber's Height
Sinks to the Level, where his Name shall rot:
Mark, with what Ease a Tyrant's Empire falls!
But yesterday, this Man's exalted Praise
Trod on the Stars: and Caesar was a God!
To Day, the insulting Foot of Rome shall spurn him,
And mix his powerless Ashes with the Dust.

sp.speaker: CIMBER.
sp.l: Hark! Was not that a Scream?

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Some Prophet Raven,
That, conscious, on the Dome's high moold'ring Roos,
Feels, and foretells, that Caesar's Ghost is rising.
sp.stage: A Noise hear'd, without, like the Fall of a Building

sp.speaker: CIMBER.
sp.l: Some horrid Ruin that!

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Look out, good Decimus.

sp.speaker: DECIMUS.
sp.l: Amazement! The long, venerable, Line
Of Statues,—All Rome's old, and aweful Chiefs
Lie fallen! And shapeless Fragments load the Floor!

sp.speaker: CIMBER.
sp.l: Shoud not a Change, like this, that mixes Palaces
With the up heaving Center, at the Moment,
When our bold Purpose moves, alarm our Caution?

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Blow, till ye burst, ye big-mouth'd Menacers!
'Tis but a Breeze, to Hearts, inflam'd for Glory.

sp.speaker: CIMBER.
sp.l: Breeze!—In such Breezes, Furies imp their Wings
Death! The Storm howls, as if the Winds felt Envy;
And woudd out-mouth the Thunder!—Call ye This
A Breeze?—my Feet want Steadiness!—The Pavement,
Heav'd, in disjointed Surge, rolls loose beneath me.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: By Heaven, tis Glorious Ruin!—Round our Heads
Fall Rome's imperial Turrets:—Earthquake, and Tempest
Plow the mix'd Elements: Noises, far heard,
Live, in the Winds, and Voice the frantic Air.
Day darkens: and the Eye of Heaven seems quench'd.
Nature's wide-loos'ning Fabrick shakes, about us!
While we, with Nerves of Steel, press on to Vengeance.
Oh! my brave Friends! What future Fame is Ours!
What Cato cou'd not—what nor Asia's Aid,
Nor Pompey's failing Fleets—not tawny Afric,
With all her Sun-defying Swarms of War!
We few—we, Roman Few—have done—this Day!

sp.speaker: CIMBER.
sp.l: One Way, or other, we shall serve the Senate:
Living, we set it free.—And, if we die,
We teach it to vote safe;—and rail, in private.

sp.speaker: DECIMUS.
sp.l: See! What a pensive Visage Brutus brings!

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Save us! He looks, as if the tumbling Statues
Had crush'd him into Cowardice!

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Rome's lost.

sp.speaker: CIMBER.
sp.l: Then, Coesar timely warn'd, has shun'd his Danger.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: No.—The last Thing, Caesar will shun, is Danger.
—Roman's! Attend; and weep your Country's Fate:
I swore the Death of Caesar:—Curse me not,
Ye Parent Gods!—I thought it due, to Rome.
To Law—to Liberty—to Man's lost Rights;
To Power's Restraint, and a deliver'd World.
The Hour—the dreadful Hour, high Heaven! I nam'd!
Ev'n now, its, last dire Moment calls on Brutus:
And now, ev'n now, Brutus is Caesar's—SON!
sp.stage: Conspirator's, all start, and look down, in a speechless Astonishment.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.l: Servilia was in secret wedlock join'd—
And gave Herself, and me—to Caesar's Love.
sp.stage: Conspirators still silent, fix'd, and amaz'd.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Is there a Roman, so benumb'd of Soul,
So firm, so passionless, so steel'd a Stoick!
So nerv'd, beyond all vulgar Strength of Man!
That he dares urge what Brutus swore to do?
Cassius!—Thou tremblest.—

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Thou shalt tremble, too,
At the last Counsel, I will live, to give thee.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Think, e're thou speak'st—for Nature is at Stake;
And, list'ning, dreads th' Advice, thou dar'st obtrude.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Mark then—were Brutus of Plebeian Mould,
Cassius wou'd say, serve on: The Tyrant Son
Shou'd aid th' Ambition of the Tyrant Father.
Rome had but mark'd two Caesar's for one Fate.
But thou wer't born her Friend—thy Name is Brutus,
And every Brutus breath'd, to bless Mankind.
Thy changeless Heart, inflexible for Virtue,
Patriots a Tyrant Blood, tho' drawn from Caesar.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Be dumb—be warn'd—'twere impious more to hear thee,

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Nay mark—thou know'st what Cataline propos'd,
When, with a Rebel Hand, he shook his Country:

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: I know it, Cassius!

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: —On that lawless Day,
When, desp'rate, he presum'd an Act, like Caesar's,
Suppose—all—wily, with a Tyrant's Craft,
This Catiline had claim'd thee, for his Son?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Roman thou wrong'st me.—

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Call me, then no Roman:

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Twas a disgraceful Question:—It imply'd,—
A Brutus might be brib'd, to wrong his Country.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Caesar yet lives.—

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: —Caesar—and Catiline!
Gods!—what Disparities thou yok'st together!
—That Caesar's Policy not feigns me His,
Learn—I have Proof, too plain.—Servilia spoke
Spoke, from the Shades of Death, and own'd me Caesar's.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Did her Ghost tell this Dream?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: The Dream is Thine,
Light Cassius!—She confess'd it, in her Letter:

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Caesar has Arts, beyond thy honest reaching,—
But, let it pass—Caesar is Caesar, still;—
Be Brutus cheated, by his Tale, or no—
He no less guilty.—Thou no less a Roman.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: If he's my Father.—

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Rome was still his Mother:
Where lives a bolder Paricide, than Caesar?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Away—my shrinking Soul abhors thy Purpose!
If I am Caesar's Son, Caesar, to me,
Is faultless:—Nature made me not his Judge.
And, till Rome's Gods redeem her, Brutus dares not.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: If Duty binds—thy Soul was Son to Cato:
He form'd thy Truth, thy Firmness, and thy Virtue:
He taught thee to revere the Gods, thou swor'st by:
And feel the sacred Force, that firms on Oath.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Perish an Oath—against the Birth, I breathe by!

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Thou but contribut'st Faith, to help Deceit!
Thou art not—can'st not be—the Son of Caesar:
I know, thou art not.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Cassius!—If I am!
—What Clash of Contradictions rends my Soul!
Horror, and Piety, divide my Virtue,
Save Caesar, all ye Gods!—But save Rome from him,

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Caesar must not be safe,—Or, Rome must fall.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Oh, Cassius! partial Hatred weighs unjustly:
Mercy so tempers his Pretence to Power,
That Tyranny grows safe—and looks, like Freedom.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS
sp.l: There is an awful Equity, that towre's
Above Men's private Passions:—Tyrants die.—
And Sons of Tyrants want their Father's Virtues:
Then bleeds a groaning State! and Right, and Rapine
Descend from Heir to Heir, for ten red Ages,
E're comes Another Caesar.—Hence, 'us Mercy,
When One Man dies, to save the Blood of Nations.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Dies, Cassius!—by a SON!—Oh! righteous Heaven!
Ayert the impending Horror!—Foe to Nature,
Hint it no more—Or, Brutus, turns the Sword,
Thou point'st at Caesar's Life—against thy own.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS,
sp.l: I've heard I am too hasty!—Judge me Romans:—
You, who have seen the Proof, that Heaven has lent me;
Judge, to what daring Length, this rash, blind, Man
Provokes his Friend's Impatience:—Let that punish thee.
Read there, what envied Rights thy Birth derives
From Caesar's Blood—who, thus, cou'd sentence Thine.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: "Wrong'd Caesar claims Redress from Curio's Sword'
"Be this his Warrant for dispatching—Brutus.
—If this was Caesar's, he believ'd me not
His Son.—and I have treated Truth, unkindly,

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Yes—thou hast thank'd us well!—these Friends!—this Cassius,
Who in the Grove, from Caesar's Murderers, sav'd
Doom'd Portia, thy Belov'd! on Death's dire Verge.
And seizing Curio, found that Warrant with him.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: By Heav'n! tis Caesar's Hand.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS,
sp.l: —Tis Caesar's Heart:
He judg'd the Virtue, like his own-Disguise:
So try'd Corruption's Power—and held out Hope
Of proud Succession: Thou, if Caesar's Son.
Wert Heir to Caesar's Empire.—Failing, there,
He found One surer Way:—Marius, his Uncle,
Had taught him, that dead Foes resist no longer.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Oh! it is all, too plain!—Come, Cassius! Cimber!
Decimus! Casca! Cinna!—Guardian Friends?
Dwell in my Bosom; share the Joy, you give:
Help me to thank the Gods, I'm once more Brutus?
Oh; I cou'd play the Wanton—let loose Pleasure;—
Laugh with the light: grow thoughtless, and forget
Rome's Danger, for a Day—to Cherish Rapture!
Now, where's the Tempest?- where's the Thunder, Now?
Loud let it rend, unfear'd, the Arch of Heaven:
Tis ominous, no longer:—let it roar
Delightful? Brutus is no Son of Caesar!
That! let it swell that Sound?—let it to Earth,
Air—Heaven, and lowest Hell's lost Hope—proclaim,
That Roman Brutus is not SON to Caesar.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Thank the kind Gods, who sav'd thee from such Horror.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Indulgent Heaven! were I like happier Roman's,
Nature had now set free my patriot Hand,
And Brutus were again, but Friend to Caesar.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS:
sp.l: Time calls;—the Senate waits us.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Stay, stay Cassius!
I feel, I know not what, of Nameless Doubting,
Still, hov'ring dark, and slack'ning half my Heart:
Oh! I am, yet, his Son.—A Friends a Father:
And That kind Title has been, ever, Caesar's.
Help Heaven! that Trumphet calls him to his Fate!
Fly, Decimus? prevent him: court him hither:
For the last Time, I'll press my Power, to save him.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Think—how expos'd thou leav'st the Friends of Rome!

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: If I betray you, may the Gods, I swore by,
Revenge your Cause! and Rome renounce my Name!

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: On thy known Truth, deserted we depend:
Fix'd in Belief, as if those Gods, invok'd,
Stood Pledges for thy Purpose.—On to the Senate.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Immortal Taskers of this fatal Moment!
Free my entangled Thoughts from gathering Darkness,
And let Rome's safety flow from Caesar's Will!
—He comes—Oh, Shade of Cato! guard my Virtue

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Retire, and wait within:—I wou'd be private.
They tell me, thou ha'st Secrets to impart:
What are they?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: —May the Soul of Rome inspire me!

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Wilt thou be Son to Caesar?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: —Caesar's Son,—
With Pride—if Caesar will be Son of Rome.—

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Again?—persumptous Weakness! know thy Duty:
Whether wou'd popular Pretension drive Thee?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: To live for Liberty—Or die for Glory:

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Thou mean'st a Substance, but thou serv'st a Name.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Rome's Senate held her Freedom more than Name.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Her Senate, rich and proud, oppress'd her People:
Her People, poor and headstrong, spurn'd their Yoke:
Hence, rose the new Necessity, thou see'st not,
Of some unformal, Self-supporting Sword,
To cut Sedition boldly, to it's Root,
And rectify the crooked Growth of Empire.
This done—regenerate Rome grown fit for Liberty,
Make it thy future Gift:—and, therefore reign.
Now, 'tis Seditian's Cloak.—Her Trumpet's Call,
That State-disturbers arm by.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Teach the Senate
These found Defects; and shape their wish'd Redress,
Theirs is the Right to think, for councell'd Rome:
Caesar a King—Were all his Virtues Stars,
Rome's Rights invading, makes his Virtues—Crimes.
Caesar a Citizen, protecting Law,
Mix'd with the People, reigns the People's God.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: What Law? what People?—Government grew Graft,
And Violation throve by Law's Protection:
Power's tott'ring Ballance shall be fix'd more justly.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: What single Hand has Right to fix Rome's Scale?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: All Men have Nature's Right, to bless their Country.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Blessings are Insuits, if by Force, impos'd.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Then Heaven, that bless'd an unconcurring World,
Insulted Nature's Freedom.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Give up the Stubborn;
Trust Rome to Rome; and Freedom, to the God.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Errors that spring from Pity, call for Pity.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Pity thy Country's Tears: the Groans of Millions!

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: I did.—and, therefore, I assum'd Dominion.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Dominion adds no Fame to Worth like Caesar's:
Nature proclaim'd Thee Noblest.—Deeds, like thine,
Raise their Performer's Rank, till King sounds poorly,
Times purple plunderers, All, shall steal thy Name,
And bid their proudest Title be but—Caesar.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Surphace, without a Depth!—false Patriots, thus,
Busied in Forms, let slip the Soul of Purpose!
While with delusive Toil, thou plow'st for Freedom,
Cheated by factious Seed, thou sow'st but Slavery.
Against One fansied Tyrant, blindly warm'd,
Thou, for a Hundred, help'st to curse thy Country.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: They curse their Country, who disturb her Peace;
And march their iron Legions, o'er her Bosom.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: I shew'd thee, obstinate, persisting Rebel!
Peace had no Root, in Rome:—Her Rights were Forms:
Her Senate—a loud Hive of insect Kings;
That robb'd, and stung: and call'd Oppression—Priviledge.
Their lawful sovereign Lord, the People—Slaves:
Slaves! in the Mockery of imagin'd Freedom!
See thy Misguiders rightly.—Trust a Father:
Affection cannot injure:—Thou art pale!
Look on me Brutus!—What new Dream disturbs thee?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: —Wake me some Roman God!

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: —Wake thee, to feel
Nature's lost Power.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS,
sp.l: —I feel it All, for Caesar.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: What woud'st thou teach my Doubts to apprehend?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Vengeance, and Death, from Romans.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Vengeance is Mine:
I won it in the Field,—to throw it back,—
And scorn'd the unmanly Trophy: Death is my Friend:
Come, when it will—tis but discharge from Care:
'Tis but to 'scape false Fears, and real Sorrows,
'Tis but to rest from Wrongs, and rise to Glory.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: There's not an unbought Roman, in the Senate,
But meditates thy Murder.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Murderers, Brutus;
Kill their own Character:—He, whom they strike,
Dies, to his Memory's Profit.—All, they can dare,
When they attempt like Men,—like Man, Itll meet.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: But shou'd they mean some dark, dishonest Blow?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Then Heav'n, that hates the base, will strike the Strikers.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: If thou can'st fear, fear All.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: To say, I cannot,
Were light:—I will not, Brutus.—Feeble Fear
Is a low, fruitless, Passion:—It unnerves
Resistance; and obscures Prevention's Eye:
Meets a'short Blow, half-way;—and aids its Weakness
Life is not worth a Fear.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Fear for Mankind;
Fear, for the sate of Rome, that loses Caesar.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: No more. I know Rome's wants, and reign, to serve he▪
Menace to me, means Nothing: spare thy Terrors:
Not ev'n the Threats of Heaven alarm the Just:
Shou'd the contending Elements break loose,
And into formless Atoms, rend the World,
The Friend of Truth must fall—but falls unshaken.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: Oh, Caesar!—my full Heart!—farewell, forever.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Brutus, in Tears!—so mourn we Griefs, we make?
Immortal Gods!—what Madness blinds Conceit!
He, who, unmov'd, resists the Voice of Nature,
Melts, in imagin'd Woes, and weeps for Rome.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS.
sp.l: No:—I but die for Rome.—I weep for Caesar,

div2.head: SCENE IV.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: What? my bold Briton—Welcome, Trinovantius,
I love thy Country's Virtues.

sp.speaker: TRINOVANTIUS.
sp.l: Caesar, hail!
When thy Friends fear—and ev'en a Brutus weeps.
May thy Gods guard thee, as thy Soldier wou'd!

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Long, has thy brave and faithful Cohort serv'd Me;
What are their Want's?—teach Caesar how please Thee.

sp.speaker: TRINOVANTIUS.
sp.l: No Briton wastes a Prayer upon Himself,
When his Friend's Life's in Danger.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: What then woud'st thou?

sp.speaker: TRINOVANTIUS.
sp.l: The Senate, met, and full of seeming Faith,
Wait thy wish'd Presence;—Rome's rais'd Throne invitee, thee,
Thy plain, well-meaning. Friends, the Populace,
Bear offer'd Incense, thro' the Streets-of Rome;
And pay their willing Worship to thy Statues.
All the pleas'd City smiles.—Yet, cou'd I move thee;
Cou'd thy old Soldier's first-felt Fear perswade;—
Caesar shou'd shun the sad-presaging Hour,
And bid this Diadem attend his Leisure.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: I thought, the Sons of Thame's had felt no Fears.

sp.speaker: TRINOVANTIUS.
sp.l: No Fears they feel from Earth's uniting Anger:
But▪ when Heaven frowns, 'tis impious, not to tremble.
All Nature, thro' her Works, seems, now, convuls'd:
—I met the palid Vestals, wildly screaming:
Fled, from the extinguish'd Fire, robeless, and bare:
And blind amidst the Dust of crumbling Towers;
Shook from the dark'nd Summits!—Doors of Sepulchre's
Untouch'd, fly open: and from silent Urns,
Where slept in Monumental Rest, the Bones
Of Rome's first Founders, slow-ascending Shades
Catch form;—and hov'ring, in the quick'n'd Air,
View some sad Fate, they want the Power to tell:
And shrink, and start—and fly the sick'ning Sun.
—Such boding Signs fore-note impending Fate:
And Heaven, from whom Kings hold, postpones thy Claim.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Fie Trinovantius!—'T is to bold for Man!
'Tis Insolence, to list the Eternal Gods:
Make Nature bus, and un-hinge a World.
To lengthen, or cut short, a Mortal's Moment?
Th' all-ruling Powers have fix'd our destin'd Space;
And we, too weak to shun, must wait their Will.

sp.speaker: TRINOVANTIUS.
sp.l: Tis whisper'd,—some great Names unite for Mischief.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Ambition, born for Contest, owes Contempt
To Threat'ners.—

sp.speaker: TRINOVANTIUS.
sp.l: Yes.—But, cautious Note of Treason,
Timely, and oft, averts the Traitor's Purpose.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: To live in daily Dread, is daily dying:
'Tisis worse than Death:—'Tis Sickness never cur'd!

sp.speaker: TRINOVANTIUS.
sp.l: Suffer my Briton's to surround the Temple,
And trust malicious Senates to their Eye.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Who awes his Enemy, submits to fear him.
—Stay, my good Friend, thou comst no farther on.

sp.speaker: TRINOVANTIUS.
sp.l: I leave thee, Caesar! with a strange Regret!
For my fore-boding Heart is filled with Terror.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Be comforted.—Thou over-rat'st my Danger.
Three hundred new Patrician's swell the Senate:
All, mine, for their own Safety:—Half the old,—
Names, like the Julian, fam'd, e're Rome was Rome!
Converts to slow-found Truth, embrace her warmly,
These, nobly owning, teach the Rest to owne,
When Error is Disgrace, Retraction's Virtue.
What apprehend'st thou, then, from that small Remnant,
Whose Weakness is too wise, to dare their With,

sp.speaker: TRINOVANTUS.
sp.l: O, Pallas! Pallas!—Guide of Martial Caesar!
How grew the Master-Soldier of the World
Unmindful, what Success, in Deeds of Blood,
Crowns unexpected Rashness!—If we but think
Th' Attempt impossible, we make it safe.
—Had (but that Heaven forbids) this unfear'd Few,
Weak as they seem, dar'd in full Senate, strike,
Firm, and combin'd, at Caesar's sacred Life;
His Friends, th' astonish'd many—powerless unnerv'd,
In Gaze of helpless Horror, had sat passive;
Each doubting each—a Foe; till Fate had reach'd thee,
And, while Prevention paus'd, Presumption triumph'd.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Briton! Thy Heart is manly: and thy Mind
Adorn'd with every Gift of Faith, and Wisdom!
Act, as thy Doubts inspire thee.—Since thou fear'st,
'Tis strange, that I, too, cannot!—Yet, beware,
Thou call'st no Aid of Arms:—Civil to Civil,
And, but to martial military.—Hear'st thou
sp.stage: Loud Cry of A Caesar—A Caesar!
sp.l: You shoutig Swarm, that shakes Rome's echoing Domes?
Lead those loud Voters, from the o'rerowded Streets,
To where their Cry may reach the Senate's Ear:
'Twill caution Guilt, perhaps! And aid Resolves.

sp.speaker: TRINOVANTIUS.
sp.l: Thanks to the Gods, thy Friends! Who led thee, once,
To charm our fraudless Isle!—By them inspir'd,
One grateful Briton saves the Roman Soul!

div2.stage: Caesar, and Trinovantius, turn to go off, on opposite Sides.

sp.speaker: TRINOVANTIUS.
sp.l: Bless thy quick Step! Com'st thou to hold back Caesar?

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Brave Islander, I do:

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Hush thy too busy Terrors.

sp.speaker: TRINOVANTIUS.
sp.l: Hold him, sweet Roman!
Tun'd Eloquence is thine: Tell him some Tale,
No matter on what Subject, make it but long,

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Why art THOU, here!—Did Brutus vote for Murder?

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Shun the met Senate:—All mean Murder, there:

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: All cannot.—Thou defam'st too broadly:—WHO?

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: The Patriot Faction.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Thou has't yoak'd Ideas,
Which Reason must divide.—Patriot, and Faction,
Like Oil on Waters, mix, when strongly shaken:
But never can unite.—disjoin'd, by Nature!

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Patriot's can envy.—And who envies—hates.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Let 'em hate on.—In Men, who love their Country,
Envy but quickens Virtue.

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: This black List
Contains O, Caesar! thirty Traitor's Names:
Traitors, by great Calphurnia's Care detected:
Traitors, who under Friendship's fair Disguise,
Have with confederate Malice, sworn thy Murder.

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: Did my Calphurnia send thee?

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Caesar, she did:

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: My Friend's Names, say'st thou, in this Roll of Traitors?

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: All thy most trusted, most distinguished Friends?

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.stage: After a Pause, returning the Roll, unopened.
sp.l: Take back thy bloody List. and hide Man's baseness:
Where Trust is tainted by such dire Deceit,
Life is not worth preserving.

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Lov'd Calphurnia.
Demands it:—for her sake, repress thy Scorn.—
Stay but to go well-guarded.

sp.speaker: CAESAR,
sp.l: Against Enemies,
Caesar suffices for the Guard of Caesar:—
But, against Friends, Distrust were Violation.

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Stay, but to be convinced—ill-fated Caesar!

sp.speaker: CAESAR.
sp.l: I will not be convinced, that Faith is Weakness.
Who wou'd take Pains to lose that Peace, he feels,
From generous Confidence in human Virtues?
If there are Wretches, who, oblig'd, betray,
'Tis Comfort, not to know 'em

div2.head: SCENE VI.
div2.stage: To TORBILIUS enter TRINOVANTIUS and two Roman Officers.

sp.speaker: TORBILIUS.
sp.l: Oh! farewell,
Rome's Fame!—Her Evil Genius has prevail'd:
And Caesar's Death shall doom declining Empire.

sp.speaker: TRINOVANTIUS.
sp.l: Stand back, keep distance; reverence the sitting Senate:
Whom will you crown your King?

sp.speaker: PLEBEIANS.
sp.l: A Caesar.! A Caesar!

sp.speaker: TRINOVANTIUS.
sp.l: Bless your concurring Joy! ye grateful People!
Caesar is yours—and you are justly Caesar's!
Crown him with Rapture.—For were Caesar King,
Rome had no Tyrants: All your lordly Patrons,
Stripp'd of oppressive Power, shall call you Brothers.
Office, with equal Eye, shall search for Skill,
And Liberty become the poor Man's Claim.
There are, who justly dread in Caesar's Crown,
His Love of the Unhappy:—dread his Pity.
He will not see the groaning Debtor sold,
To feed the rich Man's Luxury.—No Tears
Of starving Want;—no iron Hand of Law;
No Slaves to fellow-subjects, shall make sad
The Streets of happy Rome—If Caesar reigns.
sp.stage: A cry from within—Liberty! Liberty: Liberty!
sp.l: Hark! in that Cry, arose no voice of Joy!
By Heaven; they Murder Caesar! guard this Door,
Good Romans! Fulvius! Aetius! your try'd Swords,
And mine, dare enter.—Follow Me, and save him.

div2.stage: As they are going off, with their Swords drawn; they are stopt by Antony, who enters disordered.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Spare your meant Aid:—alas! it comes to late:
Murder, with all Briareus's hundred Hands,
Pierc'd the World's Soul—and Conquest is no more.

sp.speaker: TRINOVANTIUS.
sp.l: Curses consume their Names; what villain Hand!—

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Casca struck first.—Caesar, up-starting seiz'd
The assassin Steel—back plung'd it home,—and cry'd,
No—villain Casca! No—thus, thy own Poiniard
Corrects thy feeble Purpose:—die—die—Traitor!
Down to the expecting Shades—say Caesar sent thee.
There, press'd beneath a storm of Wounds, at once,
He stood, and frown'd, and bled, on every Side:
Moving at last, Majestic—the red Hand
Of miscreant Brutus met his radiant Eye.
Then thus.—All, cruel Murderers? what! All?
And Thou! My SON 1 My BRUTUS! Nay then, to conquer,
Were to perpetuate Pain:—and Death grows Joy.
Speaking, he sunk:—Soft, o'er his manly form,
Smooth'd his disorder'd Robe—and, sighless, died.
sp.stage: Cry again, from within, Liberty! Liberty!

sp.speaker: TRINOVANTIUS.
sp.l: Edge this true Sword, kind Heaven! they dare descend.

div2.stage: Advancing to meet the Conspirators, he is held back by Marc Antony.

div2.head: SCENE VII.
div2.stage: TRINOVANTIUS, ANTONY, and Officers, CASSIUS, DECIMUS, CINNA, MARCELLUS, with bloody Daggers.

sp.l: 'Tis past—Ambition bleeds; and Rome is free:
Hail Lords of Rome reviv'd! Nation of Princes.
Now once more, Masters of a World, you won!
Dare vindicate the Hands, that broke your Chain.

sp.speaker: TRINOVANTIUS.
sp.l: Cowards! cold-hearted Cowards!—You, who thus
Fear to Revenge—'tis you, have murder'd Caesar.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: No, Trinovantius.—Trust the Gods, and Rome.
With Caesar's Vengeance!—carefull, thro' the Crowd,
I seek, but find not Brutus.

sp.speaker: CIMBER.
sp.l: —Who nam'd Brutus?

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: 'Twas Antony—come forward, valiant Cimber!
Where ha'st thou left our Chief?

sp.speaker: CIMBER.
sp.l: [Unhappy Brutus!
Struck, by the Words, and Look, of dying Caesar,
He bow'd to weep upon the Wound, he made:
When, from a Gallery, bursting in, above,
Held twixt the frantic Vestals, there appear'd
Cato's yet living Sister—lost Servilia!
See! cry'd the breathless Trembler, -Traitor! Paricide!
Call'd by thy Crimes, in vain, from a Retreat,
W'ere hid, (not dead) I shun'd a hated World,
Thy Mother's blasted Eye,—fell Monster! Murderer!
Finds thee, too late: And every God shall Curse thee,
She scream'd, and sunk, amid the vestal Train.
Brutus! all Wild, as with a Fury's Horror,
Gaz'd, up, down, round—wrung his clos'd Hands—ran—stopt,
Return'd—then, with a bursting sigh, resum'd
Composure: kneel'd, and kiss'd the Robe of Caesar?
But snatching a fall'n Dagger, rose, distracted,
And cry'd—take, take me Vengeance! Rome is free:
"But Brutus, in her Cause, has stabb'd a Father!
Near, as he aim'd the meditated Blow,
I broke its erring Force—and on this Arm,
Receiv'd the pointed Mischief.—So, prevented,
I left him, 'midst a Guard of weeping Romans.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Well may he weep!—but when he reads a Charge,
The murder'd Father left the murdering Son;
What will he then endure?—what Cave has Earth,
So deep, so dark, to hide him from Himself!
When he shall see, that, to his bloody Hand;
Caesar consign'd the Power to fix Rom's Liberty.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Thou speak'st in Mystery, Marc Antony!

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Move to the Forum.—In the Face of Rome,
I shall unfold the Will of Rome's lost Guardian.

sp.speaker: CASSIUS.
sp.l: Cou'd artful Antony, prove Caesar wrong'd;
Cassius wou'd then confess, he was too hasty.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Traitor! thy willing Envy lov'd the Error:
And thou shalt expiate—far, as lowest Vice.
Too weakly can attone for murdered Virtue,
This Hour's detested Guilt, by Death and Infamy.

sp.speaker: TRINOVANTIUS.
sp.l: Summon the People:—I'll revenge this Murder;
Then, mourn lost Rome—and guard Britannia's Liberty.

sp.speaker: ANTONY.
sp.l: Had but Ambition Eyes, to look thro' Time,
Twoud see its fruitless Toil, and shun to climb:
Fondness of Noise, and Crowds of Court would cease,
And Man's whole Happiness be plac'd in Peace.
Safe Liberty would guard each Patriot Throne,
And Tyrant be, henceforth, a Name unknown:
All Fruit of Power is Pain: and what is Fame?
When ev'n a Caesar's Glory stains his Name.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: WHAT think ye Sirs, of our Quack-stage Phisician;
Who gives Folks Pills, in Verse—to cure Ambition?

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Fifty to One, he breaks:—for, to my Knowledge,
That Cure's too hard, even for our Female College!
And, (don't look silly, Sirs, when plainly told it)
Where we give out, You've poor Pretence, to hold it.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Well—but, pray, Madam!—was not this Intrusion?
Two—to One Epilogue?

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Bar—false Conclusion.
Cupid, that yokes you Smarts, nere dragg'd 'em hither,
Till broke to Female Tongues, Twice Two, together

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Nay—if They're pleas'd, I am.—your Plot? pray tell us.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: The Plot, of Petticoats—to charm the Fellows.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Hang Petticoats.—I came, to roast Sedition.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Well. and I'll souse it's Cause,—Stand clear, Ambition.
Begin.—

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Do you

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: I dare not.

sp.speaker: CALPHRNIA.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Depend on't
My Tongue, once well beginning, makes no end on't

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: No matter.—Woman's Woman's Match, nere fear it.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Is She?—come. plead the Cause—The Bench shall hear it.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Tho', born, a Maid.—and, therefore, no Man-hater.
There's ONE He Thing I loathe—and That's, a Traitor.
Factious. Contentless Monster▪—form'd to grumble.
No King can please him—and no Wife can humble.
What'ere hard Durance binds him,—(make no doubt on't)
He'll find some strange new Hole. and creep safe ou't on't.
Horrid, the Traitor's Wife's abhorr'd Condition!

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Worse, ten times worse, the Maid's, that weds Ambition!
Oh, Ladies!—too, too apt, to over rate it,
Catch a few, private Hints: and learn to hate it.
The Traitor, once for all's, but hang'd and quiet:
Th' ambitious Fribbler's Life's one, long-stretch'd, Riot.
Like a Nun's Flannel Shift, worn close, to teaze ye.
Ais Cow-itch Clasp sticks fast, and fondly yeFleas

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Now, tis my Turn to speak—Avant, SEDITION!

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Not yet, this half hour.—Ladies, fly AMBITION
Husbands, who that hard horny Taste, inherit,
Dry, like 'still Rose-Cakes, and turn, all, to Spirit.
Wrapt in Thought's Cloud, they're like (no doubt) to chear ye,

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Who see, hear, touch.—and, yet, scarce know, there near ye.
Good Friend, and dear Ally!—henceforth, uniting,
Spite of bad Patterns, let's join Hands, for Fighting.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: A Match. so join'd, each Star must Conquest, mean us.
Lord help the poor French Prig. that falls, between us!

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Say, what Ambition is.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Tis Treason's Mother:
Nurse, of Debate—

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Sly Devils! Both one, and To'ther!
What is Sedition?

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Virtue's false Pretence:
Religions Cloak,—the two-edg'd Sword, of Sense.
Tis Freedom's resty Start: Pride's patriot Plea:
Sound, that ca'nt hear: and Sight, that will not see.
Sedition! Thou art Discord never ending.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Ambition! Thou art pointing to the Head crack'd, past Power of mending
Past even St. Edward's Cure, thou dire King's Evil!
Thou first Plague Mark,—on Angel, Man, and Devil!
Snubborn as Woman's Will, thou hat'st Restriction:
And grow'st but ten Times worse, for Contradiction.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Shun plotting Heads, dear Ladies—All miscarries,
When one, that hums and haws at Midnight,—Marries,
Better, plain downright Dunce. no Dreams pursuing.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: One, that means bluntly and knows, what he's doing.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Not him, whose towr'ing Mind, estrang'd from Pleasure,
Holds him, still busiest,—when his Wife's at Leizure.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Better, a Sportsman, sound of Wind, and hearty.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Better a Sot—than Spouse dry drunk with Party.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: A hunting Husband hallows, and wé beár him.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: A drunken Deary Staggers, and we steer him.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: Each, conseious of his Wife, take Care to make her,
One Way, or other—an indulged Partaker.
But, your sage, Secret, Politician Lover,
Has nothing, fit for Woman to discover,

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: No. He's a deep, dark, pensive, Comfort-hater-Bodied for Solitude.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: And ould—for Satire.

sp.speaker: PORTIA
sp.l: Stranger, at home, he looks abroad for Blessing!
And finds whatere he has, not worth Possessing.

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA
sp.l: Freedom, and Mirth, and Health, and Joy—despises.

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: And Shuns all Rest.—He so Profoundly, wise, is!

sp.speaker: CALPHURNIA.
sp.l: At length, (Thank Heaven) he dies: kind Vapours strike him.
And leaves behind—

sp.speaker: PORTIA.
sp.l: Ten Thousand Madmen, like him,
